pos_items.definition: used after an adjective to show a person's ability to do something
dictionary_examples: I'm not very good at skiing.
He's very talented at maths.
learner_examples: She is really good at tennis. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used for emphasis in questions or negative statements, to mean in any way or of any type
dictionary_examples: Can I help at all?
He hasn't changed at all.
learner_examples: The sun was shining and there were no clouds at all, so we could see the light blue sky. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at the highest level of achievement or quality
dictionary_examples: The article is an example of journalism at its best.
learner_examples: I enjoyed this trip because we got to stay in the countryside and [see] nature at its very best. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: finally
dictionary_examples: At last, I've found a pair of jeans that actually fit.
learner_examples: At last, all of us agreed on "Cinema Farhang". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: even if nothing else happens or is true
dictionary_examples: If you can't manage to clean the whole house, at least make sure the kitchen is clean.
learner_examples: We could go shopping or at least go and have an ice-cream somewhere. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: something that you say when you are telling someone about an advantage in a bad situation
dictionary_examples: It's a small house but at least there's a garden.
learner_examples: It is not impressive but at least it has some things that I like. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at the beginning of a situation or period of time
dictionary_examples: At first I thought she was unfriendly, but actually she's just shy.
learner_examples: At first, when I arrived I was very nervous because I didn't know anyone, but then a girl started talking to me and I felt better. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If two things happen at the same time, they happen together.
dictionary_examples: We arrived at the same time.
learner_examples: The kind of clothes I most like [are] casual but fashionable at the same time. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: I knew at once that I'd like it here.
learner_examples: She called for an ambulance which came at once. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: now
dictionary_examples: At present she's working abroad.
learner_examples: Firstly, I have to tell you that at present, I am studying journalism and I have a good knowledge of computers. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to reduce the effect of a statement
dictionary_examples: I've met the President - at least, he shook my hand once.
learner_examples: But after years of developing my slalom, I wanted to learn something new, [s]o, I started Hot-Dogging. Hot-Dog is great fun. At least, people say so. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to show a price, temperature, rate, speed, etc.
dictionary_examples: He was driving at 120 mph when the police spotted him.

pos_items.definition: If something must be done at all costs, it is very important that it is done.
dictionary_examples: We have to succeed at all costs.
learner_examples: One thing was sure: he was convinced [he had] to save Anne's life at all costs. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: available for you to use at any time
dictionary_examples: We will have a car at our disposal for the whole trip.
learner_examples: But on Wednesday morning I'm at your disposal. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: responsible for something bad that has happened
dictionary_examples: I was at fault and I would like to apologize.
learner_examples: I really felt at fault. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: being in a situation where something bad is likely to happen
dictionary_examples: All houses within 100 metres of the seas are at risk of flooding.
Releasing these prisoners puts the public at risk.
learner_examples: Lives are at risk! (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: not horizontal or vertical, but sloping
dictionary_examples: He wore his hat at an angle.
The boat settled into the mud at a 35 degree angle.
learner_examples: After purchasing the G5X-1 food processor from your shop last month I discovered, upon connecting it to the mains socket and switching it on, that I needed to tilt the unit at an angle for it to work. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Others)

pos_items.definition: If you do one thing at the expense of another, doing the first thing harms the second thing.
dictionary_examples: He spent a lot of time at work, at the expense of his marriage.
learner_examples: Unfortunately one is usually done at the expense of the other. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If you accept something at face value because of the way it first looks or seems, you do so without thinking carefully about it.
dictionary_examples: You can't just accept everything you read in the newspapers at face value.
These results should not be taken at face value - careful analysis is required to assess their full implications.
learner_examples: People are assessed at face value [by] the type of cars they drive. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Amharic)

pos_items.definition: If you see something at a glance, you see it very quickly or immediately.
dictionary_examples: He could tell at a glance that something was wrong.
learner_examples: You could tell at a glance that Peter was a loner. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: near in time or space
dictionary_examples: Teachers are always close at hand to give help to any child who needs it.
learner_examples: I haven't had any lectures in English, but now and then there are lectures in English at the University so you need to understand the spoken language with no dictionary at hand. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: not less than, and probably much more than
dictionary_examples: At the very least, you should apologize.
We should earn £500 at the very least.
learner_examples: Thus, I trust you will agree that at the very least I deserve a letter of explanation from you and a substantial refund of my money. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: only a short time before something happens
dictionary_examples: I had to give a speech at very short notice.
learner_examples: The fact that the speech by the famous actor was cancelled at short notice was disappointing. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: at the same time
dictionary_examples: They all started talking at once.
learner_examples: The study centre is really small and all the students talk at once. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: suddenly
dictionary_examples: All at once he stood up and walked out of the room.
learner_examples: All at once, everything started to work again. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: chosen by chance
dictionary_examples: Winners will be chosen at random.
learner_examples: The rooms suggested to be [filmed] have not been chosen at random. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes
dictionary_examples: At times, I wish I didn't have to go to school.
learner_examples: STUDYING METHODS All teachers at the college are high[ly]-skilled professionals and can be very demanding at times, but this is [in] your best interest[s]. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: used to show that the most positive way of considering something is still not good
dictionary_examples: At best, only 50 per cent of babies born at 24 weeks will survive.
learner_examples: Then, due to the social standards, the old find themselves being abandoned and helpless. At best, such people are hospitalized. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to show that something is not good when it is the best it can be
dictionary_examples: He's not exactly patient at the best of times.
learner_examples: They knew that even at the best of times he looked unpleasant but now he was of [a] completely different [appearance]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: having problems that other people do not have
dictionary_examples: Being shy puts him at a disadvantage.
learner_examples: There would otherwise be no option for such children who would then be at a disadvantage and possibly engage in destructive behaviour. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: to not agree with someone or something
dictionary_examples: His remark was at odds with our report.
learner_examples: Young people are inexperienced as far as the world is concerned and thus they are frequently at odds with their family. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If you tell someone to do something by a particular time at the latest, you mean they must do it before that time.
dictionary_examples: She said to be there by 8 o'clock at the latest.

pos_items.definition: If you talk about something at length, you talk for a long time.
dictionary_examples: We discussed both topics at length.
learner_examples: Since we have already arranged for your family to come to stay in my home and discussed the arrangements at length and in detail, I will no longer bother you with terms of payment and other information that, judging by your letter, seems to be quite irrelevant. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.sense_title: be at liberty to do sth
pos_items.definition: to be allowed to do something
dictionary_examples: I'm not at liberty to discuss the matter at present.
learner_examples: On [the] one hand the child is at liberty to do whatever it pleases to do but on the other hand it was never taught the responsibilities implicit[l]y tied to such actions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: not knowing what to do
dictionary_examples: I'm at a loss to explain his disappearance.
learner_examples: And now I am competely at a loss what to write next. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: not knowing what to say
dictionary_examples: The question was unexpected and she was temporarily at a loss for words.
learner_examples: If it was James I would be at a loss for words, I didn't know what to tell him. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.sense_title: be at the mercy of sb/sth
pos_items.definition: to not be able to protect yourself from something or someone that you cannot control
dictionary_examples: Farmers are often at the mercy of the weather.
learner_examples: I couldn't believe I'd been careless enough to let them be at the mercy of Joanna's careless, boisterous friends, and I felt very lonely now, looking for them. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used after a time or date to show that something will not happen before then
dictionary_examples: Building will not begin until July at the earliest.

pos_items.definition: in order to make someone look stupid
dictionary_examples: Stop making jokes at my expense.
learner_examples: But despite his intellectual superiority, Piggy was subject to derision because of his physical outward appearance and the group of boys played jokes at his expense. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: If you have something at your fingertips, you can get it and use it very easily.
dictionary_examples: He had all the information needed at his fingertips.
learner_examples: An Internet connection literally means having the world at your fingertips. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If you suffer at the hands of someone, they hurt you or treat you badly.
dictionary_examples: She suffered terribly at the hands of her classmates.
learner_examples: She felt abandoned and the loss of Mark's friends at the hands of their old nemesis in the local election had left him with fewer activities for the municipality. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say what someone is really like
dictionary_examples: I'm just a kid at heart.
learner_examples: I also thought that she was brave at heart. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: most important in what is being discussed
dictionary_examples: The point at issue is what is best for the child.
learner_examples: I wouldn't like to fall into the trap of generalizing the matter at issue, but I believe there are two ways of travelling. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: If something useful is at a premium, there is not enough of it.
dictionary_examples: Time is at a premium just before the start of exams.
learner_examples: Honesty and accuracy are very good virtues to strive [for], but having friendship [and a] fair and caring relationship to your friend or partner have to be rated at a premium as well. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: If you want something at any price, you will do anything to get it.
dictionary_examples: She wanted the job at any price.
learner_examples: They wanted to be parents at any price. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used before saying what will happen if a situation continues in the same way
dictionary_examples: At this rate we're not going to be there till midnight.

pos_items.definition: used before saying one fact that is certain in a situation that you are generally not certain about
dictionary_examples: Well, at any rate we need her to be there.
learner_examples: Nevertheless, at any rate, we would like to see a society with [a] full and strong workforce working towards stronger economic power. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: If you do something at your own risk, you are completely responsible for anything bad that might happen because of it.
dictionary_examples: Customers may leave vehicles here at their own risk.
learner_examples: However, when a young man decides to go on a dangerous expedition, he should do so at his own risk and should not rely on help from anyone. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: If something is at stake, it is in a situation where it might be lost or damaged.
dictionary_examples: We have to act quickly - people's lives are at stake.
learner_examples: The whole human race's future is at stake. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: at the tender age of 8/17/25, etc.
pos_items.definition: at the young age of 8/17/25, etc
dictionary_examples: She first appeared on stage at the tender age of 14.
learner_examples: She met my father at the tender age of 14, and she soon knew that this was the man she wanted to stay with for the rest of her life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about an occasion in the past without saying exactly which occasion it was
dictionary_examples: Most of us have made a similar mistake at one time or another.
learner_examples: Haven't we all at one time or another come home from a holiday feeling healthy and strong with a smile on our face thinking, this is what life is about. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: earlier than something or someone
dictionary_examples: two days before the summer holidays
She arrived before me.
You should always wash your hands before meals.
Think hard before accepting the offer.
learner_examples: We will come before 7 o'clock and help you with dinner. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: at a place that you arrive at first when travelling towards another place
dictionary_examples: The hospital is just before the bridge.
learner_examples: Drivers've got often a problem with finding some space and there is another problem - the car park is open just until 8 pm, so the better thin[g] to do is leave a car in car park before the city centre. (First Certificate in English; B2; Czech)

pos_items.definition: in a position in front of someone or something
dictionary_examples: I've never performed this before an audience.

pos_items.definition: in front of someone or something in an order or a list
dictionary_examples: The letter K comes before L in the English alphabet.

pos_items.definition: treated as more important than someone or something
dictionary_examples: They always put the children's needs before their own.
learner_examples: She puts people with their needs before her own comfort, that is why she is successful. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: earlier than the time when something happens
dictionary_examples: He was a teacher before he became famous.
Before he could reach the door, she quickly closed it.
Before we make a decision, does anyone want to say anything else?
learner_examples: I think the notebook is in your bedroom. I was studying there before I left your home. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in order to avoid something bad happening
dictionary_examples: Put that stick down before you hurt someone!

pos_items.definition: until (the event mentioned)
dictionary_examples: It took a few moments before I realized that he was joking.

pos_items.definition: very soon
dictionary_examples: We'll be there before you know it.
learner_examples: It is a bit dark inside and especially in winter, it is dark before you know it. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: at an earlier time, or on a previous occasion
dictionary_examples: He said he had never seen her before.
I feel as though I've been here before.
learner_examples: My father never b[ought me] any birthday presents before. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: a long period of time before something
dictionary_examples: I was a vegetarian long before I met Sally.
learner_examples: The cups belonged to my family long before I was born and the fact they are [a] part of my family tradition makes them valuable in my eyes. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in the space that separates two places, people or objects
dictionary_examples: The town lies halfway between Rome and Florence.
Standing between the two adults was a small child.
She squeezed between the parked cars and ran out into the road.
A narrow path ran in between the two houses.
learner_examples: The cinema is between Laura's house and the post office. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in the period of time which separates two different events or times
dictionary_examples: You shouldn't eat between meals.
There is a break of ten minutes between classes.
The shop is closed for lunch between 12.30 and 1.30.
learner_examples: I will arrive between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: involving two or more groups of people
dictionary_examples: Tonight's game is between the New Orleans Saints and the Los Angeles Rams.
learner_examples: I would like to go shopping and then see the football match between Spain and Germany. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the largest and smallest amount or level of something
dictionary_examples: She weighs between 55 and 60 kilograms.
The competition is open to children between six and twelve years of age.
learner_examples: It's for young people aged between 18 and 30 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Somali)

pos_items.definition: connecting two or more places, things or people
dictionary_examples: There is a regular train service between Glasgow and Edinburgh.
learner_examples: We need a motorway link between the motorways 74 and 9. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: separating two places or things
dictionary_examples: The wall between East and West Berlin came down in 1989.
The gap between the rich and the poor has increased dramatically over the past decade.
learner_examples: I think that the most interesting place near my town is [the] mountains [which are] like a wall between my country and China. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: among two or more people or things
dictionary_examples: We drank two bottles of wine between four of us.
learner_examples: I think you'll have to discuss the ideas between you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in the space that separates two people, places, or things
dictionary_examples: The wood is in neat piles with newspaper placed between.
learner_examples: There is a shuttle bus from the airport straight to the main station with only one stop in between. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: in the period of time that separates two events or times
dictionary_examples: There's a train at 6.15 and one at 10.30 but nothing in between.
learner_examples: Besides, there [is] research that prove[s] that people cannot work for more than two hours [at a time]. They can't concentrate that long [and] they need to rest their minds for short periods in between. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: competing with or opposing someone or something
dictionary_examples: Germany are playing against Brazil in the final tonight.
learner_examples: I like it very much because I can play it [o]n the Internet with all of my friends and I can also form a team to play against other teams in tournaments. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: next to and touching something
dictionary_examples: Why don't we put the bed against the wall?
learner_examples: On your left there is a large window and on the right there is a desk between the two cupboards, they are against the wall. (Preliminary English Test; B1; french)

pos_items.definition: in the opposite direction to
dictionary_examples: Commuting is not so bad when you are travelling against the traffic.
learner_examples: We had to fight against the wind and the rain. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: disagreeing with a plan or activity
dictionary_examples: She spoke against the decision to close the college.
Are you for or against the proposal?
learner_examples: It is very hard to keep [a] dog because it makes too much noise and so my Mum is against it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: forbidden by a law
dictionary_examples: It's against the law to leave a young child alone in the house.
learner_examples: Until that moment, Mary thought [he]r uncle and his friends were smugglers and were doing things against the law. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to have a reason not to like someone or something
dictionary_examples: I've got nothing against him personally, I just don't think he's the right man for the job.
learner_examples: If you have nothing against taking public transport, I suggest taking a bus. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If you do something against someone's advice, wishes, etc., you do it although they have said you should not or must not.
dictionary_examples: He flew there against his doctor's advice.
She sold the house even though it was against his wishes.
learner_examples: He was a very ambitious student who wasn't afraid to develop ideas in unconventional ways and pursue his research even against the advice of his supervisors. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: If you do or achieve something against all the odds, you succeed although you were not likely to.
dictionary_examples: We won the game against all odds.
learner_examples: The stormy waters and heavy winds were a great challenge, and almost deemed it impossible for me to succeed, but against all odds I managed to defeat my fears. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: from one part of a road, river, etc. to another
dictionary_examples: a romantic walk along the beach/river
learner_examples: Last night, we walked along the Thames. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: in a line next to or beside something long
dictionary_examples: a row of houses along the river
Cars were parked all along the road.
learner_examples: To my surprise, there was a charming beach along the cycle route. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: at a particular place on a road, river, etc.
dictionary_examples: Somewhere along this road there's a garage.
learner_examples: She told me [that] along the road there are several places to visit, like a castle which is open [to the] public. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: based on and similar to something
dictionary_examples: He gave a talk along the lines of the one he gave in Oxford.
learner_examples: Imagine one is encouraged by friends and institutions for their 'different' artistic or other activities, even if their works are not along the lines of 'acceptable' norms and tradition. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: moving forward
dictionary_examples: We were just walking along, chatting.

pos_items.definition: with you
dictionary_examples: Why don't you take him along with you when you go?
I'll bring some food along and we can have a picnic.
learner_examples: My boyfriend came along with me. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: from the beginning of a period of time
dictionary_examples: I knew all along that it was a mistake.
learner_examples: In the future the key word for fashion will be comfort as this is basically what everyone has been wanting all along. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to someone or something else
dictionary_examples: California along with Florida is probably the most popular American holiday destination.
learner_examples: I speak foreign languages (English, French and Italian) along with Greek. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a particular group of people or things
dictionary_examples: Discuss it among yourselves for a few minutes.
Relax - you're among friends.
There were some good drawings among the rubbish in the pile.
learner_examples: Among my presents, my favourite one is the computer that my parents gave to me. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in the middle of something
dictionary_examples: I saw a few familiar faces among the crowd.
Rescue teams searched among the ruins for survivors.
learner_examples: If you love nature, you can eat under trees and among flowers. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to say that there are other details or examples in addition to the ones you are mentioning
dictionary_examples: It's worth visiting the museum while you're here. There's an exhibition about Darwin and a good collection of paintings, among other things.
learner_examples: To go by tram or bus is a waste of time and travel[l]ing by car is - among other things - a waste of money. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: one of the most extreme examples of a particular type
dictionary_examples: He is among the top five tennis players in the country.
learner_examples: It was among the worst zoos I have ever seen. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to each one in a group
dictionary_examples: She divided the cake among the children.
learner_examples: Although Brazil is the eighth biggest economy in the world and one of the richest countries regarding natural resources, that wealth is not shared equally among the population. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in the space that separates two places, people or objects
dictionary_examples: The town lies halfway between Rome and Florence.
Standing between the two adults was a small child.
She squeezed between the parked cars and ran out into the road.
A narrow path ran in between the two houses.
learner_examples: The cinema is between Laura's house and the post office. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in the period of time which separates two different events or times
dictionary_examples: You shouldn't eat between meals.
There is a break of ten minutes between classes.
The shop is closed for lunch between 12.30 and 1.30.
learner_examples: I will arrive between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: involving two or more groups of people
dictionary_examples: Tonight's game is between the New Orleans Saints and the Los Angeles Rams.
learner_examples: I would like to go shopping and then see the football match between Spain and Germany. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the largest and smallest amount or level of something
dictionary_examples: She weighs between 55 and 60 kilograms.
The competition is open to children between six and twelve years of age.
learner_examples: It's for young people aged between 18 and 30 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Somali)

learner_examples: We need a motorway link between the motorways 74 and 9. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

learner_examples: I think you'll have to discuss the ideas between you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: The wood is in neat piles with newspaper placed between.
learner_examples: There is a shuttle bus from the airport straight to the main station with only one stop in between. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

dictionary_examples: There's a train at 6.15 and one at 10.30 but nothing in between.
learner_examples: Besides, there [is] research that prove[s] that people cannot work for more than two hours [at a time]. They can't concentrate that long [and] they need to rest their minds for short periods in between. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

She squeezed between the parked cars and ran out into the road.
A narrow path ran in between the two houses.
learner_examples: The cinema is between Laura's house and the post office. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

dictionary_examples: You shouldn't eat between meals.

learner_examples: I will arrive between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock. (Key English Test; A2; French)

dictionary_examples: Tonight's game is between the New Orleans Saints and the Los Angeles Rams.
learner_examples: I would like to go shopping and then see the football match between Spain and Germany. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: She weighs between 55 and 60 kilograms.
The competition is open to children between six and twelve years of age.
learner_examples: It's for young people aged between 18 and 30 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Somali)

pos_items.definition: connecting two or more places, things or people
dictionary_examples: There is a regular train service between Glasgow and Edinburgh.
learner_examples: We need a motorway link between the motorways 74 and 9. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: separating two places or things
dictionary_examples: The wall between East and West Berlin came down in 1989.
The gap between the rich and the poor has increased dramatically over the past decade.
learner_examples: I think that the most interesting place near my town is [the] mountains [which are] like a wall between my country and China. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: among two or more people or things
dictionary_examples: We drank two bottles of wine between four of us.
learner_examples: I think you'll have to discuss the ideas between you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in the space that separates two people, places, or things
dictionary_examples: The wood is in neat piles with newspaper placed between.
learner_examples: There is a shuttle bus from the airport straight to the main station with only one stop in between. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: in the period of time that separates two events or times
dictionary_examples: There's a train at 6.15 and one at 10.30 but nothing in between.
learner_examples: Besides, there [is] research that prove[s] that people cannot work for more than two hours [at a time]. They can't concentrate that long [and] they need to rest their minds for short periods in between. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show the person or thing that does something
dictionary_examples: She was examined by a doctor.
We were amazed by what she told us.
I'm reading some short stories (written) by Chekhov.
The book was translated by a well-known author.
learner_examples: You have to read the "House of terror" by Constanza Vanges, [which] is about strange things that start happening in a house. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to show how something is done
dictionary_examples: They travelled across Europe by train/car.
She did the decorating (all) by herself.
Do you wish to be paid in cash or by cheque?
He learned English by listening to the radio.
learner_examples: You can go there by bus. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: not later than; at/on or before
dictionary_examples: She had promised to be back by five o'clock.
The application must be in by August 31st.
learner_examples: Please come tomorrow by 3 o'clock in the afternoon to paint my bedroom. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when you say something new or on a different subject
dictionary_examples: I think we've discussed everything we need to - by the way, what time is it?
Oh, by the way, my name's Julie.
learner_examples: By the way, I want to buy a raincoat for my brother. (Key English Test; A2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: near or next to something or someone
dictionary_examples: A small child stood by her side.
I'll meet you by the post office.
learner_examples: We'll meet by the cinema at 7.00 pm. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: holding a particular part of someone or something
dictionary_examples: She grabbed me by the arm.

pos_items.definition: as a result of an accident, mistake, etc.
dictionary_examples: I went to the wrong room by mistake.
learner_examples: I was putting my shopping bags on the table and I pushed it by mistake. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: done or made by a person instead of a machine
dictionary_examples: This sweater has to be washed by hand.

pos_items.definition: by a great amount
dictionary_examples: They are by far the best students in the class.
learner_examples: I have travelled to many countries, but New Zealand is by far the best. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: so that you can remember all of something
dictionary_examples: We had to learn the whole poem off by heart.
learner_examples: I know all his songs by heart and I was singing all the time. (First Certificate in English; B2; Bulgarian)

pos_items.sense_title: day by day/little by little/one by one, etc.
pos_items.definition: used in particular phrases to mean 'gradually' or 'in units of'
dictionary_examples: Day by day he grew stronger.
learner_examples: The weather gets warmer and warmer day by day and noone miss[es] the rain and the severe cold of winter. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to show measurements or amounts
dictionary_examples: twelve by ten metres of floor space
Interest rates have been increased by 0.25%.
I'm paid by the hour.
Copies have sold by the million.
learner_examples: Therefore you will see that this festival attracts people by the truckload. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: as said by a lot of people
dictionary_examples: The party was, by all accounts, a great success.
learner_examples: I have known Michael Van Cleef for over two decades now, and he is, by all accounts, an exemplary worker. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: in general
dictionary_examples: By and large, people have welcomed the changes.
learner_examples: By and large, it is clear that we all enjoy some kind of sport. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: If you have to do something by law, it is illegal not to do it.
dictionary_examples: They have to provide a contract by law.
learner_examples: Swedish organisations and [companies] are forced by law to put forward programmes for employing more women and improv[ing] their conditions. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: as a type of something
dictionary_examples: He sent me some flowers by way of apology.
learner_examples: The Academy however provided nothing whatsoever by way of entertainment, though with a group of interesting young people and a little imagination this should not be a pro[b]lem. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: to do something exactly as the rules tell you
dictionary_examples: If you want to get permission for the building, you'll need to do everything by the book.
learner_examples: The upper-class people always do things by the book, follow the rules and the conventions and therefore are stand-offish and cold. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to ask in a polite way whether something is possible or true
dictionary_examples: You're not Spanish by any chance, are you?
learner_examples: I pick up the phone "Hello, Nick have you by any chance got, or seen, my diary? (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: She succeeded by virtue of hard work rather than talent.
learner_examples: However, you should take into consideration the expenses, which might be exorbitant by virtue of the fact that you inten[d] to create places with a beautiful ambience and a wide range of comforts offered that will facilitate residents' lives. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: something that you say when you are agreeing to let someone do something
dictionary_examples: I have a copy of the report on my desk. By all means have a look at it.
learner_examples: The kitchen utensils stay next to the sink. You can make use of them by all means. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: in a similar way
dictionary_examples: You have to let people know your plans in good time and, by the same token, they should give you some advance warning.
learner_examples: Our college will only benefit from this event as long as it give[s] a nice and memorable impression. By the same token, we should all be well prepared and visualise beforehand possible manoeuvres that could appear, so that we can control the situation. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)
