learner_examples: It happened like a miracle, suddenly I could speak quite well and I had lots of friends and from then on, I had a very nice time and I lived the best experience I've ever live[d] in my short life. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: from the beginning of something to its end
dictionary_examples: I enjoyed the film from start to finish.
learner_examples: I found out that the service itself should last at least one and half hour[s] from start to finish. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: If you do something from scratch, you do it from the beginning.
dictionary_examples: We didn't have any furniture of our own so we had to start from scratch.
learner_examples: That means you don't have to start from scratch with your teacher. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: I've searched the house from top to bottom and still can't find it.
learner_examples: Very often we can see someone in black, from top to bottom, or in white. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: inside or towards the inside of a container, place or area
dictionary_examples: There's milk in the fridge.
Is Mark still in bed?
They live in an old cottage.
How much is that coat in the window?
What's that in your hand?
They used to live in Paris, but now they're somewhere in Italy.
My daughter's in hospital overnight.
learner_examples: He works in Austria now. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Singhalese)

pos_items.definition: during part or all of a period of time
dictionary_examples: We're going to Italy in April.
I started working here in 2007.
Life in the 19th century was very different from what it is now.
She was a brilliant gymnast in her youth.
I haven't had a decent night's sleep in years/ages.
learner_examples: I like my country in March because spring is coming. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish)

pos_items.definition: needing or using no more time than a particular amount of time
dictionary_examples: Can you finish the job in two weeks?
Dinner will be ready in ten minutes.
She could get that essay done in a couple of hours if she really tried.
learner_examples: My bedroom isn't too big, so we will finish in 1 hour. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: forming a part of something
dictionary_examples: He used to be the lead singer in a rock band.
There are too many spelling mistakes in this essay.
I've been waiting in this queue for ages.
learner_examples: My sister sings in a pop group. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: close to the front part of something or where someone can see or hear you
dictionary_examples: He parked the car in front of the house.
learner_examples: We can meet in front of the museum. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: wearing
dictionary_examples: Do you recognize that man in the grey suit?
She's always dressed in red.
learner_examples: [T]he man has to be dressed in black. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: early or at the right time
dictionary_examples: We arrived in time to catch the train.
learner_examples: If I [don']t come back in time you can put [a] note on my desk. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: before a particular time, or before doing a particular thing
dictionary_examples: If you're going to come, please let me know in advance.
learner_examples: I can help you if you want to book your room in advance. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize what is really true, or to give more information
dictionary_examples: We met Rebecca for lunch. In fact, we spent the whole afternoon with her.
I was told there were some tickets left but in fact they were sold out.
learner_examples: The club has its own small clubhouse, with many things in it. For example, there was a big pinball-game and some computers. In fact it was the best clubhouse I've ever seen. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: further forward than someone or something else
dictionary_examples: The car in front suddenly stopped and I went into the back of it.
She started talking to the man in front of her.
learner_examples: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. I beli[e]ved it was my imagination or perhaps a dream because I couldn't see anyone in front, behind or opposite me. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: liking someone very much and having romantic or sexual feelings for them
dictionary_examples: Have you ever been in love?
learner_examples: I think I am in love with him. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: experiencing an emotion or condition
dictionary_examples: She's in a bad/good mood this morning.
You're in great danger.
He's living in luxury in the south of France.
learner_examples: I hope you are in a good mood today, because we are planning to go to Cinepolis. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: arranged or divided in a particular way
dictionary_examples: We all sat down in a circle.
The desks were arranged in rows of ten.
Discounts are available to people travelling in large groups.
The books on these shelves are arranged in alphabetical order.
learner_examples: We often work in groups where we can talk in English. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: as well (as)
dictionary_examples: In addition to his flat in London, he has a villa in Italy and a castle in Scotland.
learner_examples: In addition, I saw a wonderful programme about Aborigines. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: finally, after something has been thought about or discussed a lot
dictionary_examples: We were thinking about going to Switzerland, but in the end we went to Austria.
learner_examples: And in the end he invited me to visit him at his house in Miami! (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: including or considering all the information about something or every part of something
dictionary_examples: We haven't discussed the matter in detail yet.
The book described her sufferings in great detail.
learner_examples: I'm really sorry that I didn't write back earlier, but to make up for this I will answer your questions in detail! (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: completely and with nothing missing
dictionary_examples: The bill must be paid in full by the end of the month.
learner_examples: Unfortunately, I wasn't able to read the e-mail in full, but as I underst[oo]d, he wanted to apologise [for] what had happened between us many years ago. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: beginning from now
dictionary_examples: Could you be more careful in future?
In future, I'm going to check every single piece of work that you do!
learner_examples: I hope it'll help me to understand many foreign people not only in my job, but everywhere I go in future. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech)

pos_items.definition: usually, or in most situations
dictionary_examples: In general, men are taller than women.
In general, the weather here stays sunny.
learner_examples: In general, I like wearing informal clothes, like blue jeans and T-shirts, but sometimes I like wearing formal clothes too. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: crying
dictionary_examples: I found him in tears in his bedroom.
learner_examples: By the end of it, Mary Anne was nearly in tears. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Bengali)

pos_items.sense_title: in order (for sb/sth) to do sth
pos_items.definition: with the purpose of achieving something
dictionary_examples: He came home early in order to see the children before they went to bed.
She worked all summer in order to save enough money.
learner_examples: As you certainly remember, last year I spent three month[s] in England in order to improve my English. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: considering the whole of someone or something, and not just a particular part of them
dictionary_examples: So, apart from the bad ankle, how are you in general?
learner_examples: I think that I, as well as people in general, would have been more depressed if we didn't have light. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to agree with or approve of a plan or idea
dictionary_examples: Most people are in favour of reducing traffic in cities.
learner_examples: I am certainly in favour of h[o]lding the music festival next year. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: divided into two equal parts
dictionary_examples: Cut the potatoes in two.
Divide the dough in half and roll it out into two circles.
learner_examples: They were very surprised when they found the gold was cut in half. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize what is really true, or to give more information
dictionary_examples: I thought she was Portuguese, but in actual fact she's Brazilian.
learner_examples: Nowadays almost all people own a car and in actual fact more and more people have been facing death as a consequence of careless driving. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: expressed or written in a particular way
dictionary_examples: They spoke in Russian the whole time.
Why not do a rough answer in pencil first?
Complete the form in (black) ink.
learner_examples: I also speak in English during the break. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

pos_items.definition: especially
dictionary_examples: Are you looking for anything in particular?
learner_examples: I've read a lot of books recently, and in particular I liked: "Eleven minutes" and "Veronica decides to die", written by Paulo Coelho. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: involved or connected with a particular subject or activity
dictionary_examples: a degree in philosophy
advances in medical science
I never knew you worked in publishing.
learner_examples: He is my age and we have the same tastes in music and art. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: because of a possibility of something happening, being needed, etc.
dictionary_examples: I don't think I'll need any money but I'll bring some just in case.
Bring a map in case you get lost.
learner_examples: I have my mobile with me just in case. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: when something happens, or in preparation for when something happens
dictionary_examples: We keep a bucket of water backstage, in case of fire.
learner_examples: It is about how to rescue people in case of an accident or a natural disaster. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to give another reason for something you are saying, or that you have done
dictionary_examples: I don't want to go and in any case, I haven't been invited.
learner_examples: I suggest that you should in any case leave your car at home and take buses or other public means of transport. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: because of the mentioned situation
dictionary_examples: There's no coffee left? In that case I'll have tea.
learner_examples: You could try [k]ayaking. In that case, of course, you need to pay for the equipment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: used to show the total amount of something
dictionary_examples: Some of the children came, so there were 15 of us in all.
learner_examples: Secondly, even though most people like[d] [the] group RADIANT, they [only] played for 35 minutes in all. (First Certificate in English; B2; )

pos_items.definition: used when referring to something that is done as a result of something else
dictionary_examples: I'd like to do something for you in return/exchange for everything you've done for me.
The changes are in response to demand from our customers.
He refused to say anything in reply to the journalists' questions.
learner_examples: I am writing to you in response to your advertisement of 1st December in the Times. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: using only a few words
dictionary_examples: world news in brief
learner_examples: In brief, I have had a marvellous week. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in someone's opinion
dictionary_examples: In my parents' eyes, I'll always be a child.
learner_examples: To answer your question right away, the boat trip is highly recommendable in my eyes! (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to introduce the last part of a speech or a piece of writing
dictionary_examples: In conclusion, I would like to thank our guest speaker for her fascinating talk.
In conclusion, swimming is an enjoyable form of exercise and an excellent way to keep fit.
learner_examples: In conclusion, music, TV and clothes are very important in a young person's life and can reflect each person's character. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to say what something is about
dictionary_examples: I am writing in connection with the above job advertised in The Daily Press on Monday 12th February.
A man has been arrested in connection with last month's murder.
learner_examples: Dear Mrs Brown, I am writing in connection with a surprise birthday party for your husband, Mr Brown. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: at a suitable time in the future
dictionary_examples: The results will be sent to you in due course.
learner_examples: I look forward to hearing from you in due course. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: towards someone
dictionary_examples: She keeps looking in my direction.
learner_examples: A player kicked the ball in my direction and I started to think about what I was going to do to catch that ball. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to explain what something means in a different way
dictionary_examples: He said he's too busy - in other words he isn't interested.
learner_examples: They had had a great time before and had drunk too much alcohol. In other words, they were totally drunk. (First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: An agreement that is in writing is official and is proof of that agreement.
dictionary_examples: Please confirm your reservation in writing.
learner_examples: I [am] tell[ing] you in writing that I would like to help you. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: if vegetables or fruit are in season, they are available and ready to eat.
dictionary_examples: Asparagus is in season at the moment.
learner_examples: They celebrate Halloween in October when pumpkins are in season, that's why in the decorations they include them very often; most of the people carve the pumpkins and put some lights inside. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: without telling other people
dictionary_examples: For years they met in secret.
learner_examples: We met in secret when Mary was busy. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: feeling good/excited/unhappy, etc.
dictionary_examples: The whole class was in good spirits that day.
learner_examples: I was in high spirits until I got my paper back. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: because of
dictionary_examples: In view of recent events, we have decided to cancel the meeting.
learner_examples: In view of what happened, I would advise you not to try to mislead people like this [again]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in order to celebrate or show great respect for someone or something
dictionary_examples: a banquet in honour of the president
learner_examples: Finally we went to Corinth, where there are a lot of ancient sanctuaries which were built in honour of their gods. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: If you do something in person, you go somewhere to do it yourself.
dictionary_examples: You have to collect the document in person.
learner_examples: I am looking forward [to] meeting you in person. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: instead of something
dictionary_examples: Try adding fruit to your cereal in place of sugar.
learner_examples: In the advertisement, it [said] that Danny Brook was starring, but in place of him there was a different actor and he was really disap[p]ointing. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: at the start of a situation
dictionary_examples: Why did you invite her in the first place?
learner_examples: In the first place, you were unknown people for me, but now you are my special foreign friends. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: If something is true in practice, this is the real situation.
dictionary_examples: In practice, the new laws have had little effect.
learner_examples: When you leave school, you have knowledge but you do not know how to use it in practice. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in a place where nobody else can hear you or see what you are doing
dictionary_examples: The meeting was held in private.
learner_examples: I agree that th[is] should be in private. (First Certificate in English; B2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: happening or being done now
dictionary_examples: Repair work is in progress on the south-bound lane of the motorway and will continue until June.
learner_examples: [In] the lower part of your advertisement, it also said there was a theatre restaurant, [but] in fact, it was closed because internal decoration was in progress. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: when compared with something
dictionary_examples: Salaries are low in relation to the cost of living.
learner_examples: I think television has several advantages but also disadvantages in relation to books. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: about or relating to something
dictionary_examples: I'd like to ask you something in relation to what you said earlier.
learner_examples: In relation to last month's social program, the sightseeing tour of London was d[i]vine, although we didn't get to see the entire city. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a particular way, or in many ways
dictionary_examples: The school has changed in many respects.
learner_examples: How's your friend Mike? He is in many respects better than [a] computer, isn't he? (Teasing you again, sorry). (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: as an answer to
dictionary_examples: I'm writing in response to your letter of 14 February.
learner_examples: I am writing in response to your advertisement, which appeared in the newspaper on November the 23rd, looking for a person to work at weekends in your cafe. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: one after another without a break
dictionary_examples: He's just won the tournament for the fifth year in a row.
learner_examples: Maradona was the captain of the team, and since he arrived, the team won three championships in a row. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: available in a shop
dictionary_examples: Do you have the book in stock at the moment?
learner_examples: I would like to tell you that I am quite satisfied with the cinema and its customer service, but there is of course some [room] for improvement - for example referring to the cafe, which on the one hand has in stock a huge variety of groceries, but [which] on the other hand [is very] dark. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about a period in the past
dictionary_examples: In those days, boys used to wear short trousers.
learner_examples: In those days, life was much harder than now. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: one after another
dictionary_examples: He spoke to the three boys in turn.

pos_items.definition: as a result of something that is part of a series of events
dictionary_examples: This could result in the loss of certain species of fish and this in turn poses a serious threat to the fishing communities along the river banks.
learner_examples: This, in turn, enabled them to find jobs and become financially independent from their husbands. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in the way described by a rule, law, or wish
dictionary_examples: Both companies have insisted that they were acting in accordance with the law.
learner_examples: Although they do not earn much money in this profession, they try to do their best and judge in accordance with the law which they also have to interpret. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: in order to collect money for a group of people who need it
dictionary_examples: a concert in aid of famine relief
learner_examples: It w[ould] be an honour for us students at the centre if you could attend our sport[s] function in aid of stress[ed] out kids and present the pri[z]es. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: working together with
dictionary_examples: The event was organized in association with the Sports Council.
learner_examples: This service, which will be [provided] in association with Foster Loft, will be available at the end of 2005. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: in large amounts
dictionary_examples: to buy in bulk
learner_examples: I suggest that you buy food in bulk so that you not only save money but also save time. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: in the same way as someone or something
dictionary_examples: In common with many working mothers, she feels guilty about leaving her children.
learner_examples: In common with many city d[we]llers, I do not think this is a wise decision and it could have negative effects on the city re[s]idents' daily lives. (Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Mandarin)

pos_items.definition: wanted or needed in large numbers
dictionary_examples: Good teachers are always in demand.
learner_examples: Nevertheless, people will always use cars and vehicles, so petrol will always be in demand. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: if something happens
dictionary_examples: An airbag could save your life in the event of an accident.
learner_examples: In the event of bad weather, it would be wise to plan an alternative to the boat trip, for example a visit of Buckingham Palace or the Houses of Parliament. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: whatever happens
dictionary_examples: I'm not sure if I'm coming on Friday, but in any event, I'll see you next week.
learner_examples: In any event, it is incumbent upon all of us to carefully plan our travel matters, so as to take advantage of their several benefits. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be famous and often featured in the media
dictionary_examples: Her new role means that she will be in the public eye.
learner_examples: But being famous also means that you are always in the public eye, which is a major drawback. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: If something is in your favour, it helps you to win or succeed.
dictionary_examples: Both sides have strong arguments in their favour.
learner_examples: Unfortunately the weather conditions were not in our favour, but the rain only lasted a few minutes and did not look at all like a downpour. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: the particular way in which something appears or exists
dictionary_examples: The novel is written in the form of a series of letters.
The medicine comes in the form of a liquid or pills.
learner_examples: For all this, I can only say that I want my money back immediately, or [some] compensation in the form of a real trip to a real country. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to say what you really think
dictionary_examples: In his heart he felt they were wrong.
learner_examples: It is all because it was followed by a big mistake, when I focussed on [the] German language and thought is was my dream. I have to admit that it was only a [sensi]ble decision, because deep in my heart I knew I want[ed] to learn English. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: because you want something good to happen
dictionary_examples: She went to Paris in the hope of improving her French.
They wrote to the Prime Minister in the hope that he would help.
learner_examples: Not only would I want to travel back to understand Hitler's incredible success, but also in the hope of thwarting his plans. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: to help someone and give them an advantage
dictionary_examples: It may not be in your interests to change jobs so soon.
learner_examples: It is in my interests to meet new people and I find it easy to go and talk to people I do not know. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: If something is done or happens in the light of facts, it is done or happens because of those facts.
dictionary_examples: The drug has been withdrawn in the light of new research.
learner_examples: In the light of this news, we took this issue as a class project and investigated it by interviewing residents. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: If you do something in moderation, you do not do it too much.
dictionary_examples: I only drink alcohol in moderation now.
learner_examples: While shopping can make one feel good and even has its positive impact on the retail economy, I think it should be done in moderation. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog)

pos_items.definition: to have difficulty making a decision
dictionary_examples: I'm in two minds about accepting his offer.
learner_examples: If you are in two minds about having to share your room with someone else, there you can easily rent a studio apartment close to the college, which is situated in the centre of the city. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: something that you say when you are describing something using as few words as possible
dictionary_examples: The answer, in a nutshell, is yes.
learner_examples: To put it in a nutshell, they all provide good food at reasonable prices. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: If someone or something is in position, they are in the place that they should be in.
dictionary_examples: The police were all in position.
learner_examples: Remember to stay calm when you are in the car with the instructor, wear your seatbelt and check that all your mir[r]ors are in position. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: approximately
dictionary_examples: It probably cost somewhere in the region of £900.
learner_examples: I am willing [to] pay rent in the region of £1000 to £1200 monthly. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: relating to a particular thing
dictionary_examples: I include payment in respect of your invoice of May 13th.
learner_examples: Instead of that, we should have more English grammar lessons - some of our English students are very interested in them, especially in respect of their exam this year. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: in the opposite order or way
dictionary_examples: Do the same steps but this time in reverse.
learner_examples: They want to see what they are not like, how they would not react and this, in reverse, helps them [to] find themselves. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: very soon
dictionary_examples: We'll be home in no time.
learner_examples: Team work is very important for us and you will make many friends in no time. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: singing or playing the right notes
dictionary_examples: Try to stay in tune.
learner_examples: The public was singing in tune with Jag, hands were raised and bodies were slowly [sway]ing. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: as a result of something that is part of a series of events
dictionary_examples: This could result in the loss of certain species of fish and this in turn poses a serious threat to the fishing communities along the river banks.
learner_examples: This, in turn, enabled them to find jobs and become financially independent from their husbands. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: without any success
dictionary_examples: I tried in vain to start a conversation.
learner_examples: We looked in vain for the guide through three London parks. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.sense_title: in no way/not in any way
pos_items.definition: not at all
dictionary_examples: This is in no way your fault.
learner_examples: This magazine will be loved by students as it will help them learn English in the best way and in no way will students find it boring. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: thinking about something in a particular way
dictionary_examples: In a sense, he's right.
learner_examples: In a sense this is correct, since you have to leave your natural environment to visit a place where no human being is meant to survive. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in a few words
dictionary_examples: In short, we need more staff.
learner_examples: In short, ancient Chinese poems, mainly [from the] Jang D[yna]sty, constitute [the] background for Chinese culture and set a touchstone for judgement in our life. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: going to happen soon
dictionary_examples: You never know what's in store for you.
There's a bit of a shock in store for him when he gets home tonight!
learner_examples: Nobody knows what the future will have in store! (Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to show when doing one thing is the cause of another thing happening
dictionary_examples: In refusing to work abroad, she missed an excellent job opportunity.
The government banned tobacco advertising and, in doing so, contributed greatly to the nation's health.
learner_examples: According to Montaigne's point of view, children and even "older" people ought to travel as much as possible. In doing so, they would receive an education that no school could provide them with. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: not knowing about something because other people are not telling you
dictionary_examples: They kept us in the dark about their plans.
learner_examples: Peter had always kept her in the dark about the reason for their fight. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: expecting something to happen or in preparation for something happening
dictionary_examples: She's even decorated the spare room in anticipation of your visit.
learner_examples: This has sometimes resulted in the comic phenomenon of people travelling to a distant country, in anticipation of encountering strange and original lifestyles, only to come across situations not very different [from] the one they have left in their own countries. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: present at an event
dictionary_examples: They have doctors in attendance at every match.
learner_examples: Professional coach[e]s are in attendance and the members can have proper lessons. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: to feel great respect for and sometimes fear of someone
dictionary_examples: As children we were rather in awe of our grandfather.
learner_examples: As I was the eldest of [the] siblings, they used to respect all my orders and [even] now, they are a bit in awe of me. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.sense_title: in the blink of an eye
pos_items.definition: extremely quickly
dictionary_examples: In the blink of an eye, he was gone.
learner_examples: And for all those who keep nagging about losing their favourite regular programmes during such an event, be patient: TV routine will be back into your living rooms in the blink of an eye. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: in a cruel way, without showing any emotion
dictionary_examples: He shot three policemen in cold blood.
learner_examples: Returning to the story, when I arrived, I went directly to Hillton Avenue where I should have met 005, but when I arrived at the meeting point I found him lying on the floor with two shots in his back; he had been murdered in cold blood. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: to be in the same unpleasant situation as other people
dictionary_examples: She complains that she doesn't have enough money, but we're all in the same boat.
learner_examples: Unemployment and its consequences is still a major problem. Now we are in the same boat. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: not in a difficult situation or having problems any more
dictionary_examples: We have had money problems but we should be in the clear by next year.
learner_examples: "You're in the clear, you don't have to be afraid any more", it said. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If you tell something to someone in confidence, you do not want them to tell anyone else.
dictionary_examples: I'm sorry, she told me that in confidence.
learner_examples: His real name isn't Piggy but he told Ralph in confidence that they called him that in school because of his appearance. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: working, used, or happening with something or someone else
dictionary_examples: Our librarians use their knowledge in conjunction with the computer network.
learner_examples: Therefore if the banning of private cars takes place in conjunction with development in the public transport system in that city, this whole development will [have] more advantages despite some slight difficulties at the start. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: If bad things are done in the name of something, they are done in order to help that thing succeed.
dictionary_examples: So much blood has been spilt in the name of religion.
learner_examples: Recently, a Swedish priest compared homosexuality to cancer, and he did it in the name of religion. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in the area near a place
dictionary_examples: A number of buildings in the vicinity of the fire were damaged.
learner_examples: This centre would provide new sports and leisure premises for our town and would certainly attract young people from other towns in the vicinity as well. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone or something does something to a large degree
dictionary_examples: They celebrate birthdays in a big way.
learner_examples: Tourism helps Greece's national economy - which is not at its best - in a big way. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used when you repeat what someone said
dictionary_examples: In the manager's words, the game was 'a total disaster'.
learner_examples: In the immortal words of the bard "... if music be the food of love....... play on!" (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: almost certainly
dictionary_examples: The facilities are wasted on people who in all likelihood will not use them.
learner_examples: In all likelihood, you will have to work during the weekends, even in summer, so I firmly believe that loving your job is very important. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: to be similar to and suitable for something
dictionary_examples: They were offered a pay increase in line with inflation.
learner_examples: The other two courses, at 5%, are still in line with the national average. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans)

pos_items.definition: If you do something in memory of a dead person, you do it to show your respect or love for them.
dictionary_examples: They built a statue in memory of those who died in the fire.
learner_examples: You see, every year our family performs a certain gathering in memory of my brother who was killed in a plane crash in 1991 known as the C130 disaster. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: in your imagination or memory
dictionary_examples: In my mind's eye, she remains a little girl of six although she's actually a grown woman.
learner_examples: He sees her in his mind's eye, running around barefoot, laughing and squealing, wading in the water and running back out, screaming, trying to get away from the breaking waves. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If something is in miniature, it is a very small copy of something else.
dictionary_examples: a model of the ship in miniature
learner_examples: Thirdly a co-educational school is a society in miniature and it has many practical advantages. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.sense_title: be in the mood for sth/to do sth
pos_items.definition: to want to do or have something
dictionary_examples: I'm not really in the mood for shopping at the moment.
learner_examples: Should you be in the mood for a walk around the lake then go for it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to say what the real situation is
dictionary_examples: This means, in effect, that the plan has been scrapped.
learner_examples: However, if the government increases the amount of money they pay to the unemployed, that in effect means higher taxes for the citizens which will cause strikes and various other problems. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize the most important idea or quality of something
dictionary_examples: In essence, its purpose is to contain information.
learner_examples: In essence, homelessness means that you don't have a home and because of this you are living on the streets. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: while having to deal with a difficult situation or problem
dictionary_examples: She refused to leave him, in the face of increasing pressure from friends and family.
learner_examples: No doubt, it was rather difficult to like Enid X. She was hardly likely to arouse sympathy in anybody even in the face of death. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If you refuse or get rid of someone or something in favour of someone or something else, you choose them instead.
dictionary_examples: They dropped him from the team in favour of a much younger player.
learner_examples: The city council should revise the airport project [... and] change the current location of the airport in favour of a more isolated area. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: immediately, or very quickly
dictionary_examples: I'll be back in a flash.
learner_examples: He took it and, in a flash, he came up to the surface. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: being worked on or dealt with now
dictionary_examples: Despite the pressures we are determined to get on with the job in hand.
learner_examples: Miss Kenton keeps asking Stevens whether everything is in hand and whether her help is required. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used when you are saying what you really think or feel about something
dictionary_examples: In all honesty, I'd rather not go.
learner_examples: It is easy to say that government funding should be raised to make classes smaller and materials more relevant, but in all honesty, Danish schools are working very well indeed. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to give your opinion about something, often when you are sure you are right
dictionary_examples: In my humble opinion, that's the wrong decision.
learner_examples: In my humble opinion, there's no such thing as a uniform celebrity, good, bad or otherwise. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: Something that is in its infancy has only just begun to develop.
dictionary_examples: In the 1950s, space travel was in its infancy.

pos_items.definition: in order to achieve a particular situation or quality
dictionary_examples: In the interest of safety, passengers are advised to wear their seat belts at all times.
learner_examples: First of all, do make sure that the front door is always locked. In the interests of everybody's security, it is essential to remember [this]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: alone, or separately from other people, places, or things
dictionary_examples: These poems cannot be considered in isolation.
learner_examples: In conclusion, it is my opinion that the problem of parking space cannot be solved in isolation. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans)

pos_items.definition: partly
dictionary_examples: He is in part to blame for the accident.
learner_examples: Technology is in part to blame. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: when things are in perspective, you think about them in a sensible and realistic way, and understand how important or unimportant they really are
dictionary_examples: You must keep things in perspective - the overall situation isn't really that bad.
When you see pictures of their suffering, it puts your own problems in perspective.
learner_examples: I think it will enable me to see things more in perspective. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: in the correct position
dictionary_examples: The chairs are all in place.
learner_examples: I looked neat and clean even after the wildest games in the school yard, with all the ribbons that tied my long hair in place. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If a rule, system, etc. is in place, it has started to exist.
dictionary_examples: There are now laws in place to prevent this from happening.
learner_examples: Let's take [the] example of Mexico City, where such restrictions have been in place since early 2000. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: If you agree with something in principle, you agree with the idea or plan although you do not know the details or you do not know if it will be possible.
dictionary_examples: They have approved the changes in principle.
learner_examples: In principle, one can agree with both positions pointed out in this statement. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to mean that something is very likely
dictionary_examples: She will, in all probability, have left before we arrive.
learner_examples: Anybody who can fulfill the above conditions will in all probability be successful. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something is being done, and something else happens in the process, the second thing happens as a result of doing the first thing.
dictionary_examples: She stood up to say hello and spilled her drink in the process.
The tunnel was built, but many lives were lost in the process.
learner_examples: If an attempt is made to move them to another location they will probably die in the process. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: be in the process of doing sth
pos_items.definition: to have started doing something
dictionary_examples: We're in the process of painting our apartment.
learner_examples: This feeling of affinity is especially important for young people and teenagers who are in the process of creating their own identity and I also believe that sportsmen and sportswomen make great role models. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If something changes in proportion to another thing, it changes to the same degree as that thing.
dictionary_examples: Your tax payment increases in proportion to your salary.
learner_examples: One aspect of the question is the fact that a sportsman's salary is supposedly not in proportion to the number of hours he work[s]. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: the person or thing that is being discussed
dictionary_examples: He claims that he was in the pub with his girlfriend on the night in question.
learner_examples: While this is not necessarily false, it should be borne in mind that the events in question are by no means boring or uninteresting. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If your bank account is in the red, you have spent more money than there was in it.
dictionary_examples: I expect I'm in the red again.
learner_examples: Her bank account was in the red. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: thinking now about something in the past
dictionary_examples: In retrospect, I should probably have told her.
learner_examples: But now I could in retrospect conclude that it was too much: that tat[t]oo displaying a cannabis leaf should have been enough for me to at least wonder [whether] something was really wrong with my son. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: in a bad situation where you do the same things all the time, or where it is impossible to make progress
dictionary_examples: He seems to be stuck in a rut at the moment.
learner_examples: Financial security, all the, let me call them, background benefits are important, but if you do not love what you do, soon you will become bitter, stuck in a rut or worse - you will suffer from depression. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be acceptable in a way that will not upset or anger people
dictionary_examples: His speech was in good taste.
learner_examples: I therefore t[h]ought that it would be in good taste to write about two of them. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to be unacceptable in a way that will upset or anger people
dictionary_examples: He told a joke about a plane crash which I thought was in rather poor taste.

pos_items.definition: in a direct and often angry way
dictionary_examples: I told him to go away in no uncertain terms.
learner_examples: Intellectuals are used to saying in no uncertain terms that money represents the bad side of the sport. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to understand what someone wants or needs or to understand a situation and act in a way that is suitable for it
dictionary_examples: The government is not in tune with the voters.
learner_examples: I am not exactly in tune with all the latest trends but I know which styles give me the most satisfaction. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: because of or for this reason
dictionary_examples: The course is good in that it provides a very practical training.
learner_examples: Nowadays it is widely argued that professional sports are damaging to people's health in that they involve gruelling training sessions as an integral part of the occupation. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: into an area or space from the outside of it
dictionary_examples: Could you bring the clothes in for me?
Cut the pastry into a square and turn in the corners.
learner_examples: First I brought in the big cake that my father had [bought]. (Key English Test; A2; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: at the place where a person usually lives or works
dictionary_examples: Mr Ellis isn't in this week.
Could you ask him to ring me when he gets in?
learner_examples: My neighbour wasn't in. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Lithuanian)

pos_items.definition: having arrived at the place where people can get on or off
dictionary_examples: What time is Roz's flight due in?

pos_items.definition: given or sent to someone official in order to be read
dictionary_examples: When does your essay have to be in?
Remember to get your application in by the end of the week.

pos_items.definition: If someone is in for a surprise, treat, shock, etc., it will happen to them soon.
dictionary_examples: If he thinks looking after a baby is easy, he's in for a shock.
learner_examples: Holidays do revive the spirit and renew the soul, provided you have a positive attitude towards life and bear in mind that they are just a fragment of real[i]ty. Otherwise, you are in for a disappointment. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: the ins and outs of sth
pos_items.definition: the details of a particular subject
dictionary_examples: the ins and outs of the legal system
learner_examples: I knew all the ins and outs of every story but I couldn't stay one single day in bed without reading it. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: intended to be given to or used by someone or something
dictionary_examples: There's a phone message for you.
I'd better buy something for the new baby.
learner_examples: This is my information for you. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show an amount of time or distance
dictionary_examples: She's out of the office for a few days next week.
I'm just going to rest for an hour or so.
I haven't played tennis for years.
We drove for miles without seeing anyone.
learner_examples: I had a break for 20 minutes. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to give an example of the type of thing you mean
dictionary_examples: I like soft fruit, for example, peaches and plums.
Some people, students for example, can get cheaper tickets.
learner_examples: Also he likes to do sports, for example swimming and c[ycl]ing. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: having a particular purpose
dictionary_examples: There's a sign there saying 'boats for hire'.
Which vitamins should you take for skin problems?
learner_examples: You [need] to bring your exer[c]ise book for art. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in order to get or achieve something
dictionary_examples: I hate waiting for public transport.
I had to run for the bus.
Did you send off for details of the competition?
I've applied for a job with another computer company.
learner_examples: It's important to me because I['m] going to study for an exam. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in exchange for something, especially an amount of money
dictionary_examples: How much did you pay for your glasses?
She sold the house for quite a lot of money.
They've said they'll repair my car for £300.
learner_examples: I['m] sell[ing] it for 100 Euro. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: on the occasion of
dictionary_examples: What did you buy him for Christmas?
We're having a party for Jim's 60th birthday.
learner_examples: I'm tired because I ha[d] a party yesterday for my birthday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: at a particular time
dictionary_examples: I've booked a table at the restaurant for nine o'clock.
We can give you an appointment for 10.15.
learner_examples: Can we rearrange the time for five o'clock? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: because of or as a result of something
dictionary_examples: He got fined for travelling without a ticket.
The things you do for love!
Scotland is famous for its beautiful countryside.
He's best remembered for his novels.
learner_examples: It is famous for "paella" but we have many dif[f]erent kind[s] of food. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: showing meaning
dictionary_examples: What's the Czech word for 'book'?
"What does J.L. stand for?" "José Luis."

pos_items.definition: towards or in the direction of
dictionary_examples: They looked as if they were heading for the train station.
Just follow signs for the town centre.
This time tomorrow we'll be setting off for the States.
It says this train is for Birmingham and Coventry only.

pos_items.definition: available to buy
dictionary_examples: Is this painting for sale?
Our neighbours put their house up for sale last week.
learner_examples: For sale: "Olympus" camera + bag. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: in order to help someone
dictionary_examples: I'll carry those bags for you.
learner_examples: I'd like to do something helpful for them. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: being employed by or representing a company, country, etc.
dictionary_examples: She works for a charity.
He plays football for Cambridge United.
He used to swim for his country when he was younger.
learner_examples: He works for a company in Mexico. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: always in the future
dictionary_examples: I'm not going to live here for ever.
learner_examples: My friend was leaving the city for ever and [going] to a city in another country. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: for fun or for the fun of it
pos_items.definition: for pleasure and not for any other reason
dictionary_examples: I ran but just for fun.
learner_examples: Fortunately I discovered that [the email] wasn't for me. I didn't appreciate that there were people that were sending things like that just for fun. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: without any doubts
dictionary_examples: I think he's Canadian but I don't know for sure.
One thing's for sure - once the baby's born, your lives will never be the same again.
learner_examples: For sure, you'll love Brazil. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: for example
dictionary_examples: In the electronics industry, for instance, 5000 jobs are being lost.
learner_examples: For instance, you can do mountain walks. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: in support of or in agreement with
dictionary_examples: I voted for the Greens at the last election.
So let's hear some applause for these talented young performers.
learner_examples: There are a lot of votes for and against keeping animals in cages. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If you do something for the moment, you are doing it now, but might do something different in the future.
dictionary_examples: Let's carry on with what we agreed for the moment.
learner_examples: For the moment I am unemployed so I have plenty of time to give [you] a hand. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to mean that something is happening that does not usually happen
dictionary_examples: For once, the bus came on time.
learner_examples: We would take lots of pictures, and play our own instruments, and if we get lucky enough, we would even touch the very stones and for once be embraced by magic itself. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: taken seriously, not pretended
dictionary_examples: I thought it was just a practice, but apparently it was for real.
learner_examples: You know I am a Casanova, but this time I know [it] is for real. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say whose responsibility something is
dictionary_examples: I can't tell you whether you should go or not - that's for you to decide.
learner_examples: It is for you to decide whet[h]er my colleagues should take part in this kind of course or not, but all in all I would like to recommend this course. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: when compared to a particular fact
dictionary_examples: She's quite tall for her age.
learner_examples: She spends all day indoors "stuffing" her craving for knowledge with books quite hard for her age. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: forever
dictionary_examples: When he was 20, he left home for good.
learner_examples: He was renting this property previously, but he went back to Sri Lanka for good. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese)

pos_items.definition: for the whole of someone's life
dictionary_examples: I will have to take this medicine for life.
learner_examples: A wedding opens a new life when the two parties commit to each other for life. (International English Language Testing System; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: for a long time
dictionary_examples: Have you been waiting for long?
learner_examples: There're departures every half an hour to the city centre, so you won't have to wait for long. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: mostly or usually
dictionary_examples: I enjoyed it for the most part.
learner_examples: First of all, for the most part, people have to use computers in their jobs. (International English Language Testing System; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: for now but not permanently
dictionary_examples: I'm living with my parents for the time being.
Leave the ironing for the time being - I'll do it later.
learner_examples: I think that is all for the time being. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving the first in a list of reasons or things
dictionary_examples: I won't be going - I've got too much homework for a start.
learner_examples: So this creates an awareness of the obligation to look after oneself for a start. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: despite
dictionary_examples: For all her qualifications, she's useless at the job.
learner_examples: For all of his desire to be strong, Okonkwo is haunted [by] fear. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: in order to help someone
dictionary_examples: We bought the piano for the children's benefit.
learner_examples: Needless to say, I hope you take [all this] into consideration not only for Gustavo's benefit, but also for the benefit of the astronaut training programme and the world. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If something is for the best, it seems unpleasant now, but will improve a situation in the future.
dictionary_examples: Divorce is always painful, but it really was for the best.
learner_examples: It's a kind of sad thing to think about but maybe it's for the best. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: because you are worried about something/doing something
dictionary_examples: I didn't want to move for fear of waking her up.
learner_examples: No one dared to turn around for fear of being bitterly disappointed. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to give a reason for something
dictionary_examples: You can't give Amy that shirt - for one thing it's too small for her.
learner_examples: Well, for one thing, you cannot spy on your subjects 24 hours a day - they would not allow it, and it would be prohibitively expensive. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: intended to be given to or used by someone or something
dictionary_examples: There's a phone message for you.
I'd better buy something for the new baby.
learner_examples: This is my information for you. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show an amount of time or distance
dictionary_examples: She's out of the office for a few days next week.
I'm just going to rest for an hour or so.
I haven't played tennis for years.
We drove for miles without seeing anyone.
learner_examples: I had a break for 20 minutes. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to give an example of the type of thing you mean
dictionary_examples: I like soft fruit, for example, peaches and plums.
Some people, students for example, can get cheaper tickets.
learner_examples: Also he likes to do sports, for example swimming and c[ycl]ing. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: having a particular purpose
dictionary_examples: There's a sign there saying 'boats for hire'.
Which vitamins should you take for skin problems?
learner_examples: You [need] to bring your exer[c]ise book for art. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in order to get or achieve something
dictionary_examples: I hate waiting for public transport.
I had to run for the bus.
Did you send off for details of the competition?
I've applied for a job with another computer company.
learner_examples: It's important to me because I['m] going to study for an exam. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: How much did you pay for your glasses?
She sold the house for quite a lot of money.
They've said they'll repair my car for £300.
learner_examples: I['m] sell[ing] it for 100 Euro. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: on the occasion of
dictionary_examples: What did you buy him for Christmas?
We're having a party for Jim's 60th birthday.
learner_examples: I'm tired because I ha[d] a party yesterday for my birthday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: at a particular time
dictionary_examples: I've booked a table at the restaurant for nine o'clock.
We can give you an appointment for 10.15.
learner_examples: Can we rearrange the time for five o'clock? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

dictionary_examples: He got fined for travelling without a ticket.
The things you do for love!
Scotland is famous for its beautiful countryside.
He's best remembered for his novels.
learner_examples: It is famous for "paella" but we have many dif[f]erent kind[s] of food. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: showing meaning
dictionary_examples: What's the Czech word for 'book'?
"What does J.L. stand for?" "José Luis."

pos_items.definition: towards or in the direction of
dictionary_examples: They looked as if they were heading for the train station.
Just follow signs for the town centre.
This time tomorrow we'll be setting off for the States.
It says this train is for Birmingham and Coventry only.

pos_items.definition: available to buy
dictionary_examples: Is this painting for sale?
Our neighbours put their house up for sale last week.
learner_examples: For sale: "Olympus" camera + bag. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: in order to help someone
dictionary_examples: I'll carry those bags for you.
learner_examples: I'd like to do something helpful for them. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: being employed by or representing a company, country, etc.
dictionary_examples: She works for a charity.
He plays football for Cambridge United.
He used to swim for his country when he was younger.
learner_examples: He works for a company in Mexico. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: always in the future
dictionary_examples: I'm not going to live here for ever.
learner_examples: My friend was leaving the city for ever and [going] to a city in another country. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: for fun or for the fun of it
pos_items.definition: for pleasure and not for any other reason
dictionary_examples: I ran but just for fun.
learner_examples: Fortunately I discovered that [the email] wasn't for me. I didn't appreciate that there were people that were sending things like that just for fun. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: without any doubts
dictionary_examples: I think he's Canadian but I don't know for sure.
One thing's for sure - once the baby's born, your lives will never be the same again.
learner_examples: For sure, you'll love Brazil. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: for example
dictionary_examples: In the electronics industry, for instance, 5000 jobs are being lost.
learner_examples: For instance, you can do mountain walks. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: in support of or in agreement with
dictionary_examples: I voted for the Greens at the last election.
So let's hear some applause for these talented young performers.
learner_examples: There are a lot of votes for and against keeping animals in cages. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If you do something for the moment, you are doing it now, but might do something different in the future.
dictionary_examples: Let's carry on with what we agreed for the moment.
learner_examples: For the moment I am unemployed so I have plenty of time to give [you] a hand. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: used to mean that something is happening that does not usually happen
dictionary_examples: For once, the bus came on time.
learner_examples: We would take lots of pictures, and play our own instruments, and if we get lucky enough, we would even touch the very stones and for once be embraced by magic itself. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: taken seriously, not pretended
dictionary_examples: I thought it was just a practice, but apparently it was for real.
learner_examples: You know I am a Casanova, but this time I know [it] is for real. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say whose responsibility something is
dictionary_examples: I can't tell you whether you should go or not - that's for you to decide.
learner_examples: It is for you to decide whet[h]er my colleagues should take part in this kind of course or not, but all in all I would like to recommend this course. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: when compared to a particular fact
dictionary_examples: She's quite tall for her age.
learner_examples: She spends all day indoors "stuffing" her craving for knowledge with books quite hard for her age. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: forever
dictionary_examples: When he was 20, he left home for good.
learner_examples: He was renting this property previously, but he went back to Sri Lanka for good. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese)

pos_items.definition: for the whole of someone's life
dictionary_examples: I will have to take this medicine for life.
learner_examples: A wedding opens a new life when the two parties commit to each other for life. (International English Language Testing System; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: for a long time
dictionary_examples: Have you been waiting for long?
learner_examples: There're departures every half an hour to the city centre, so you won't have to wait for long. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: mostly or usually
dictionary_examples: I enjoyed it for the most part.
learner_examples: First of all, for the most part, people have to use computers in their jobs. (International English Language Testing System; C1; French)

pos_items.definition: for now but not permanently
dictionary_examples: I'm living with my parents for the time being.
Leave the ironing for the time being - I'll do it later.
learner_examples: I think that is all for the time being. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are giving the first in a list of reasons or things
dictionary_examples: I won't be going - I've got too much homework for a start.
learner_examples: So this creates an awareness of the obligation to look after oneself for a start. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: despite
dictionary_examples: For all her qualifications, she's useless at the job.
learner_examples: For all of his desire to be strong, Okonkwo is haunted [by] fear. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: in order to help someone
dictionary_examples: We bought the piano for the children's benefit.
learner_examples: Needless to say, I hope you take [all this] into consideration not only for Gustavo's benefit, but also for the benefit of the astronaut training programme and the world. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: If something is for the best, it seems unpleasant now, but will improve a situation in the future.
dictionary_examples: Divorce is always painful, but it really was for the best.
learner_examples: It's a kind of sad thing to think about but maybe it's for the best. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: because you are worried about something/doing something
dictionary_examples: I didn't want to move for fear of waking her up.
learner_examples: No one dared to turn around for fear of being bitterly disappointed. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to give a reason for something
dictionary_examples: You can't give Amy that shirt - for one thing it's too small for her.
learner_examples: Well, for one thing, you cannot spy on your subjects 24 hours a day - they would not allow it, and it would be prohibitively expensive. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: intended to be given to or used by someone or something
dictionary_examples: There's a phone message for you.
I'd better buy something for the new baby.
learner_examples: This is my information for you. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show an amount of time or distance
dictionary_examples: She's out of the office for a few days next week.
I'm just going to rest for an hour or so.
I haven't played tennis for years.
We drove for miles without seeing anyone.
learner_examples: I had a break for 20 minutes. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to give an example of the type of thing you mean
dictionary_examples: I like soft fruit, for example, peaches and plums.
Some people, students for example, can get cheaper tickets.
learner_examples: Also he likes to do sports, for example swimming and c[ycl]ing. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: having a particular purpose
dictionary_examples: There's a sign there saying 'boats for hire'.
Which vitamins should you take for skin problems?
learner_examples: You [need] to bring your exer[c]ise book for art. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: in order to get or achieve something
dictionary_examples: I hate waiting for public transport.
I had to run for the bus.
Did you send off for details of the competition?
I've applied for a job with another computer company.
learner_examples: It's important to me because I['m] going to study for an exam. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in exchange for something, especially an amount of money
dictionary_examples: How much did you pay for your glasses?
She sold the house for quite a lot of money.
They've said they'll repair my car for £300.
learner_examples: I['m] sell[ing] it for 100 Euro. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: on the occasion of
dictionary_examples: What did you buy him for Christmas?
We're having a party for Jim's 60th birthday.
learner_examples: I'm tired because I ha[d] a party yesterday for my birthday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: at a particular time
dictionary_examples: I've booked a table at the restaurant for nine o'clock.
We can give you an appointment for 10.15.
learner_examples: Can we rearrange the time for five o'clock? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: because of or as a result of something
dictionary_examples: He got fined for travelling without a ticket.
The things you do for love!
Scotland is famous for its beautiful countryside.
He's best remembered for his novels.
learner_examples: It is famous for "paella" but we have many dif[f]erent kind[s] of food. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: showing meaning
dictionary_examples: What's the Czech word for 'book'?

pos_items.definition: towards or in the direction of

learner_examples: For sale: "Olympus" camera + bag. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: in order to help someone
