pos_items.definition: driving or travelling, usually over a long distance
dictionary_examples: We'd been on the road for 48 hours.
learner_examples: I have experienced sitting behind a steering wheel on the road for many years. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai)

pos_items.definition: making progress and likely to succeed
dictionary_examples: A fighter from Edinburgh is on track to become world heavyweight boxing champion.
We've got a lot of work to do but we're on the right track.
learner_examples: The sales teams are well on track and bringing [in] new customers every day. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: being shown to the public
dictionary_examples: Her designs are currently on show at the Museum of Modern Art.
learner_examples: One of the facilit[ies] that really make[s] a difference is the Art Gallery, with its great exhibition on show, as well as the Art Library. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: inside a factory, office building, etc.
dictionary_examples: There are two restaurants on site.
They provide on-site childcare facilities for employees.
learner_examples: A small period of training on site is required a few days before the beginning of the job itself and how many interesting people you will meet! (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the verge of sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to happen or do something very soon
dictionary_examples: The company is on the verge of financial disaster.
learner_examples: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take the control of my own life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to have something with you
dictionary_examples: Do you have your driving licence on you?

pos_items.sense_title: on no account; not on any account
pos_items.definition: not for any reason or in any situation
dictionary_examples: On no account must these records be changed.
learner_examples: Mary did not want Martin to leave on any account, let alone move to a foreign country. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the brink of sth
pos_items.definition: to be in a situation where something bad is going to happen very soon
dictionary_examples: The two countries are on the brink of war.
learner_examples: By the end of the 21st century, Earth was on the brink of destruction. The atmosphere was polluted, the seas were poisoned, the animals were just a distant memory. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be likely to happen
dictionary_examples: Do you think marriage is on the cards?

pos_items.definition: to be extremely happy and excited
dictionary_examples: After I heard I'd got the job, I was on cloud nine!
learner_examples: But now, after the promise in which both said "yes", she was on cloud nine. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: at that exact time
dictionary_examples: We have to leave at 7.30 on the dot.
learner_examples: He gave him an address and told him to be there at six on the dot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: sometimes, but not often
dictionary_examples: I only drink alcohol on occasion.
learner_examples: As I am writing this I am begin[n]ing to conclude that there are very few disadvantages of banning private cars, only that for individuals it is far easier and [more] conven[i]ent to use a private car and not rely on our public transport, which can be on occasions very unreliable. (International English Language Testing System; C2; English)

pos_items.sense_title: be on the verge of sth/doing sth
pos_items.definition: to be going to happen or to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: a company on the verge of financial disaster
learner_examples: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take control of my own life. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If two people are on the same wavelength, they have the same way of thinking and it is easy for them to understand each other.
dictionary_examples: We chatted occasionally, but I never really felt we were on the same wavelength.
learner_examples: We were on the same wavelength and we therefore started our own research. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If someone's job, reputation, life, etc. is on the line, they may lose it.
dictionary_examples: If we don't win the contract, all our jobs are on the line.
learner_examples: The person who hopes to achieve success shouldn't be afraid of taking risks and sometimes putting his or her career on the line for the sake of gaining much bigger benefits. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to be nervous or worried
dictionary_examples: Sorry for shouting - I'm a bit on edge today.
learner_examples: I was consequently on edge all the time and was not able to have fun as much as the others did. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used when you are describing how a situation seems on the surface
dictionary_examples: On the face of it, it seems like a bargain, but I bet there are hidden costs.
learner_examples: On the face of it, both sides have valid arguments, and it's a difficult balancing act to manage. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu)

pos_items.definition: If someone is in form or on form, they are feeling or performing well, and if they are off form they are not feeling or performing well.
dictionary_examples: Harry was on good form last night.

pos_items.definition: to be ready to deal with something difficult that might happen
dictionary_examples: Companies were warned to be on their guard for suspicious packages.
learner_examples: However, we should be on guard, so as not to let the things escape our control. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: near to someone or something, and ready to help or be used when necessary
dictionary_examples: Extra supplies will be on hand, should they be needed.
learner_examples: From their point of view, they can always have you on hand whenever they need help, which is the most important part in their formative years. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: suddenly and without thinking first
dictionary_examples: I tend to act on impulse.
learner_examples: I'm seeing Milly as a capricious girl who, like most teenagers, enjoy[s] buying, although I think that she buys on impulse. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan)

pos_items.sense_title: on the part of sb; on sb's part
pos_items.definition: done or experienced by someone
dictionary_examples: This is a major sacrifice on the part of the unions.
The accident was caused by carelessness on the instructor's part.
learner_examples: It seems that international sports competitions have always tended to attract a great amount of interest on the part of the media and have consistently been popular with sports fans the world over. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: If you refuse to do something on principle, you refuse to do it because you think it is morally wrong.
dictionary_examples: She doesn't wear fur on principle.
learner_examples: They granted themselves a little celebration: it was time to keep the promise made four years before; so they bought some bottles of wine and got drunk (the[y] who, on principle, never drank alcohol). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in addition to your main job
dictionary_examples: She does a bit of bar work on the side.
learner_examples: At work, they gave her the worst jobs to do. She knew she didn't have much choice but she still tried to find something else on the side. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: I accepted the job on the spot.
learner_examples: And when it was Meredith's turn to tell her about her impending wedding, she felt she was going to have a heart attack on the spot. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: on the spur of the moment
pos_items.definition: If you do something on the spur of the moment, you do it suddenly, without planning it.
dictionary_examples: On the spur of the moment we decided to go to London for the day.
learner_examples: In reality, many people buy things on the spur of the moment only to discover later that they, in fact, do not [meet] their expect[at]ions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: at the start of a new and important time or development
dictionary_examples: We're on the threshold of a new era in European relations.
learner_examples: On the threshold of the third millen[n]ium, there is no stopping progress. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If you have something on, you are wearing it.
dictionary_examples: She's got a black coat on.
Why don't you put your new dress on?
learner_examples: And I want you to put on some baggy clothes, so that you'll feel comfortable while working. (Key English Test; A2; Rajasthani)

pos_items.definition: into a bus, train, plane, etc. or onto a horse
dictionary_examples: The train suddenly started moving as I was stepping on.
Her horse began to move as soon as she was on.

pos_items.definition: happening or planned
dictionary_examples: I'm busy tomorrow, but I've got nothing on the day after.
I've got a lot on at the moment.
Do you know what's on at the cinema?
Is the party still on for tomorrow?

pos_items.definition: performing
dictionary_examples: Hurry up with the make-up - I'm on in ten minutes.
The audience cheered as the band came on.
learner_examples: My faith in youth started to fade but then a boy named Josh came on. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in a way which results in forward movement
dictionary_examples: You cycle on and I'll meet you there.
Move on, please, and let the ambulance through.
learner_examples: I had just got [o]n the subway when it stopped and didn't move on. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: working or being used
dictionary_examples: The heating has been on all day.
learner_examples: For example, the staff shouldn't leave the lights [on] and the heating's on when they don't need to use it. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to show movement into or on a particular place
dictionary_examples: I slipped as I stepped onto the platform.
The crates were loaded onto trucks.
learner_examples: We couldn't talk so much, because the music was very loud till a group of singers came onto the dance floor and [did] a great show. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to show that you are starting to talk about a different subject
dictionary_examples: How did we get onto this subject?
learner_examples: Let's move onto another topic! (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: no longer in a particular place or area
dictionary_examples: Take the main road out of the city.
He has been out of the country for a long time.
learner_examples: When you arrive please come to my home and then we can go there because it's out of the city. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container
dictionary_examples: A peach rolled out of the bag.
I jumped out of bed and ran downstairs.
learner_examples: Once he told me that he and his other friend saw a cat falling out of a window. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used to show what something is made from
dictionary_examples: The dress is made out of silk.
The statue was carved out of a single block of stone.
learner_examples: I love clothes which are made out of cotton. These are perfect for this hot weather. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: from among an amount or number
dictionary_examples: Nine out of ten people said they liked the product.
No one got 20 out of 20 in the test.
learner_examples: He got 99.4 out of 100, "Oh my God". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: no longer in a particular condition or situation
dictionary_examples: The patient is now out of danger.
learner_examples: She told me that D was out of danger and that she will have other information tomorrow. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to show the reason why someone does something
dictionary_examples: I took the job out of necessity because we had no money left.
Just out of interest, how much did it cost you?
I only went there out of curiosity.
learner_examples: When the warrior had left, the explorer [explored the cave] out of curiosity and [to] his big surprise found the treasure. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to have no more of something left
dictionary_examples: We're nearly out of petrol.
learner_examples: By then I was out of money so I start[ed] walking. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: old and no longer useful, correct or fashionable
dictionary_examples: These unemployment figures are out of date.
learner_examples: The library has got very poor staff and most of it is out of date. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: If a machine or system is out of order, it is not working as it should.
dictionary_examples: The coffee machine's out of order.
learner_examples: Last week my TV was out of order. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: not in a job
dictionary_examples: I've been out of work for the last six months.
Both she and her husband are out of work.
learner_examples: Right now I am out of work and would like to try som[e]thing different for a while. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: to be breathing quickly because you have been running, walking fast, etc.
dictionary_examples: He burst into the room, red-faced and out of breath.
learner_examples: I find that shopping is very good exercise too! By the time you have completed the whole High Street, you will be out of breath. (First Certificate in English; B2; Thai)

pos_items.definition: If something or someone is out of control, you cannot influence, limit or direct them.
dictionary_examples: The car skidded and went out of control, crashing into an oncoming truck.
learner_examples: I had just driven through Piazza Duomo, when another car came round a corner much too fast, skidded, and went out of control. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: If someone or something appears out of nowhere, it appears suddenly or unexpectedly.
dictionary_examples: The car came out of nowhere and we had to swerve to miss it.
learner_examples: I was lying all alone on the beach, then suddenly, out of nowhere, right behind me those strange creatures appeared. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: to not do something well because you have not done it recently
dictionary_examples: I didn't play very well today - I'm out of practice.
learner_examples: I think playing in the club will be a great opportunity for me so as not to be out of practice. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: not available in a shop
dictionary_examples: The book is out of stock at the moment.
learner_examples: And sometimes the item you are looking for is out of stock. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: If vegetables or fruit are out of season, they are not usually available at that time.
dictionary_examples: Strawberries are out of season at the moment.
learner_examples: As our place was famous for fresh sea food, I bought crabs and salmon although they were out of season and expensive. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: singing or playing the wrong notes
dictionary_examples: The piano is out of tune.
learner_examples: Even if you sing out of tune please call us. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something happens out of the blue, it is completely unexpected.
dictionary_examples: One day, out of the blue, she announced that she was leaving.
learner_examples: Dear Kim, I was extremely happy when I received your letter out of the blue. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: damaged or hurt and not able to operate or play sports
dictionary_examples: I'm afraid my car's out of action.
They've got three players out of action.
learner_examples: The air-condition[ing] in my room was out of action and the hotel manager didn't care. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: not having the knowledge, experience, or skills to deal with a particular subject or situation
dictionary_examples: When they start talking about philosophy, I'm completely out of my depth.
learner_examples: It was my first day of school. What I can remember is that I really felt out of my depth: my parents were so happy that I couldn't succeed in telling them that I was terribly frightened and that [the only] thing that I wanted was my doll. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: without a job
dictionary_examples: How long have you been out of a job?
learner_examples: So, what is so terrible about being out of a job, you might ask yourself. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: unusual or different
dictionary_examples: Their relationship was a little out of the ordinary.
The investigation revealed nothing out of the ordinary.
learner_examples: This event is something out of the ordinary for local life and it gives our town prestige and originality. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to be of extremely good quality
dictionary_examples: Their chocolate cake is just out of this world!
learner_examples: The dessert trays are out of this world. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: If someone's actions or words are out of line, they are not suitable or acceptable.
dictionary_examples: Her remarks to the press were way out of line.
learner_examples: Today I see that my mother was right in this aspect since I acted extremely out of line sometimes and a soft hand certainly wouldn't help me in the future. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to become difficult to control
dictionary_examples: It was the end of term and the children were getting a little out of hand.
learner_examples: A few solutions can prevent this problem from getting out of hand. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not in the correct position
dictionary_examples: Why are my files all out of place?
learner_examples: It was awful getting back from school and se[e]ing all my things out of place. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: not right or suitable for a particular situation
dictionary_examples: Everyone else was wearing jeans and I felt completely out of place in my office clothes.
learner_examples: This does not mean everybody is wearing tuxedos and dresses but you might be out of place just wearing shorts and a shirt. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: If something is out of proportion, it is much bigger or smaller than it should be, when compared to other things.
dictionary_examples: The punishment is completely out of proportion to the crime.
learner_examples: If you were doing it to make a profit, I could understand, but for a library it is just out of proportion [and] I even believe more people could be attracted [if] the prices decrease. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: If something is out of the question, it is not possible or not allowed.
dictionary_examples: Providing more money is out of the question.
learner_examples: Walking home was out of the question since that would have taken even longer. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: If you go somewhere out of season, you go during a period of the year when few people are there.
dictionary_examples: I prefer to travel out of season.
learner_examples: Some towns [that] are completely dependent on tourism "die" out of season, while others are destroyed because of the excessive emigration of [their] people. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: not healthy or physically strong
dictionary_examples: Since I stopped cycling, I'm very out of shape.
learner_examples: I no longer run and it has been more than a year since the last time I raced, [so] I am out of shape. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to know little about what has recently happened
dictionary_examples: I've been abroad for the last two years, so I'm very out of touch.
learner_examples: In much worse cases, some individuals may even be trapped in the virtual world and get out of touch with the real one. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount, number, or age
dictionary_examples: Most of the bikes cost/are over £300.
Children over the age of 12 must have full-price tickets.
They are already $25 million over budget.
learner_examples: We have to dance in a school and over two hundred people [will watch] us. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: covering something or someone
dictionary_examples: Put a blanket over you to keep warm.
I put my hands over my eyes because I didn't want to see.
learner_examples: Wear an apron over your clothes. (Key English Test; A2; Hindi)

pos_items.definition: above or higher than something
dictionary_examples: The sign over the door said "Exit".
A flock of geese flew over the trees.
She held the umbrella over both of us.
learner_examples: Besides that, you have voted for the construction of a new bridge over the main street. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: across from one side of something to the other, especially by going up and then down
dictionary_examples: She jumped over the gate.
The road goes over the mountains.
She is always chatting with her neighbour over the garden fence.
From the top of the tower you could see for miles over the city.
Tanks travel over the most difficult ground.
learner_examples: I most enjoyed [it] when we [were] cycling over the hills, because there weren't any people and it was peaceful and qui[et]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: everywhere in a particular place
dictionary_examples: Soon the news was all over town.
learner_examples: The people in the class are from all over the world. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: during a particular period of time
dictionary_examples: I was in Seattle over the summer.
We discussed the matter over lunch.
It's fascinating to watch how a baby changes and develops over time.
learner_examples: He apologised for the trouble and when he heard that they just wanted to stay over the weekend, he said they should go and buy the most important things and enjoy the weekend as the suitcase wo[uld]n't arrive until Monday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: on the other side of
dictionary_examples: There's a pub over the road we could go to.
The story continues over the page.
The station is over the bridge.

pos_items.definition: in control of or teaching someone or something
dictionary_examples: A good teacher has an easy authority over a class.
She's a sales manager but she has a regional sales director over her.
The victory over the French at Waterloo was Wellington's greatest triumph.
learner_examples: Fortunately, my parents do not wield authority over me and my siblings like dictators. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: using
dictionary_examples: They spoke over the phone.
We heard the news over the radio.
learner_examples: She laughed over the phone, and said "It's really like you". (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: in this/that place
dictionary_examples: Put your bags down over there.
learner_examples: How is everything over there? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: connected with or about
dictionary_examples: It's stupid arguing over something so trivial.
learner_examples: The teams themselves suffered from these money problems: recently strikes broke out in basketball teams in the U.S when players began to argue over money. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: too extreme and not suitable
dictionary_examples: I thought her performance was way over the top.
learner_examples: In addition to that, many so-called "stars" have that certain over the top attitude, which would not be welcome in normal life. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount or level
dictionary_examples: People who are 65 years old and over can get half-price tickets.
learner_examples: In my opinion, the minimum working age being 18 and over, I think the school leaving age should be limited to just 16. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Others)

pos_items.definition: from one side or place to another
dictionary_examples: She leaned over and kissed me.
Why don't you come over for dinner on Thursday?
I've got a friend over from Canada this week.
Now we're going over to Wembley for commentary on the Cup Final.
learner_examples: He came over to me and we talked a while. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: describes the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up
dictionary_examples: She turned another page over.
learner_examples: A big truck had turned over and blocked the road and there was no other way for us to go, so we had to wait. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: finished
dictionary_examples: I'll be glad when the competition is over.
I used to have a thriving business and a happy marriage, but that's all over now.
learner_examples: David smiled triumphantly and said, "It is all over!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: happening or done many times
dictionary_examples: I read the article over and over till it made sense.
learner_examples: I've been searching in newspapers over and over again and finally after a couple of days I found something. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
learner_examples: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to do something difficult or unpleasant as soon as you can so that you do not have to worry about it any more
dictionary_examples: I got all my apologies over and done with at the beginning of the meeting.
learner_examples: Not to mention that he knew that he had to get his degree over and done with before he started making serious decisions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: because of
dictionary_examples: The concert has been cancelled owing to low ticket sales.
learner_examples: To start with, [it] is a great idea to change rooms because the[y] are too crowded, owing to the fact that there a lot of people. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: belonging or relating to someone or something
dictionary_examples: a friend of mine
the colour of her hair
part of the problem
employees of the company
learner_examples: The name of my friend is Maria. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used after words which show an amount
dictionary_examples: a kilo of apples
loads of food
hundreds of people
most of them
none of them
both of us
a third of all people
a drop of rain
learner_examples: She has a lot of flowers in her room. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: containing
dictionary_examples: a bag of sweets
a bottle of beer
a book of short stories
sacks of rubbish
learner_examples: I like cups of tea, I like noodles, but I don't like beef. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Mandarin)

pos_items.definition: used with numbers, ages and dates
dictionary_examples: an essay of 500 words
a boy of six
the 14th of February 2005
learner_examples: The class started [on] the 2nd of June at half past five. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say 'yes' and emphasize your answer
dictionary_examples: "Can you help me?" "Of course!"
learner_examples: Yes of course I can come. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used in expressions showing position
dictionary_examples: the top of his head
the back of your dress
on the corner of the street
the front of the queue
I've never been north of Edinburgh.
learner_examples: First you [go] pas[t] [a] big supermarket on the corner of my street. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: showing someone or something
dictionary_examples: a map of the city centre
a photo of my boyfriend
learner_examples: Tony gave me a photo of Henry. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used when comparing related things
dictionary_examples: Best of all I liked the green one.
Worst of all was the food!
He's the best looking of the three brothers.
I think that of all his films it's my favourite.
learner_examples: The best of all was a necklace. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used to say 'no' and emphasize your answer
dictionary_examples: "Do you mind if I borrow your pen?" "Of course not."
learner_examples: "Pardon. You said your [u]ncle's will? Would you mind explaining [that], please?" "Of course not!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to show who or what does something
dictionary_examples: the works of Shakespeare
the arrival of the rainy season
the music of the flute
learner_examples: They often cover the music of "The Beatles" or "The Rolling Stones". (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: showing a reason or cause
dictionary_examples: He died of cancer.
learner_examples: But, three months later, after walk[ing] in the rain he died of pneumonia. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show that what you are saying is obvious or already known
dictionary_examples: Of course, the Olympics are not just about money.
learner_examples: Of course, I met many new people. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used after an adjective when judging someone's behaviour
dictionary_examples: It was very nice of you to think of us.
It was a bit mean of him to mention her weight.
Thank you so much for my present. How thoughtful of you.
learner_examples: It was most thoughtful of you to invite us and I warmly appreciate your hospitality. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: about or relating to
dictionary_examples: Speaking of Elizabeth, here she is.
Let us consider the events of the last five months.
We know very little of her childhood.
learner_examples: Speaking of sightseeing, many thought that visiting other sights - like the Folk Museum - should not be compulsory. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

pos_items.definition: If you do something of your own accord, you choose to do it and no one else forces you.
dictionary_examples: She left of her own accord.
learner_examples: She would go alone, but it was something that was chosen of her own accord. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: close in distance
dictionary_examples: Is there a train station near here?
We were near the exit.
The hotel is near the airport.
Don't come too near me - you might catch my cold.
Which bus stop is nearest (to) your house?
I moved my chair nearer to the fire.
learner_examples: The park is near my house, about 10 minutes on foot. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: close in time
dictionary_examples: He arrived near the end of the lesson.
It was nearer four when we finally arrived.
We can decide which route to take nearer the time.

pos_items.definition: almost in a particular state or condition
dictionary_examples: The runners looked near exhaustion.
I was near (to) tears at one point during the film.
This is the nearest I've ever got to winning anything.
He came near to punching him.
learner_examples: It is strictly related to the fact that the old possess a vast amount of experience and are nearer to death. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: not close in distance, time, amount or quality
dictionary_examples: The house was nowhere near the sea.
It's nowhere near time for us to leave yet.
I'm nowhere near finishing the book - I'm only half-way through it.
He's nowhere near as tall as his sister.
learner_examples: Although people are well aware of the current situation in Switzerland, they prefer looking at other countries and comparing us to them (we are nowhere near as fat as them). (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: used in questions and negatives to mean 'close to being or doing something'
dictionary_examples: The house isn't anywhere near ready.
learner_examples: We could not have gone anywhere near 5000 miles because all our minibuses were broken down - we even stayed in one place for 8 days. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: close in distance
dictionary_examples: I was standing just near enough to hear what they were saying.
Don't come any nearer.
learner_examples: And they are getting nearer, I must run for my life. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: close in time
dictionary_examples: Her birthday was getting nearer and I still hadn't bought her a present.
As the date of his operation drew near, he became more and more anxious.
learner_examples: I would appreciate very much if you could reply as soon as possible, as the school holiday is drawing near. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: close in distance
dictionary_examples: Where's the nearest post office?
learner_examples: Dear Dan, My friends and I have decided to go to the nearest cinema, the one which is in The Mall, three blocks from here. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: at a time that is not far away
dictionary_examples: Space travel may become very common in the near future.
learner_examples: I look forward to receiving your reply in the near future. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: similar in characteristics or quality
dictionary_examples: My pocket knife is the nearest thing to a weapon that I have.
I couldn't get any cream cheese so I bought the nearest equivalent that I could find.

pos_items.definition: more than a particular amount, number, or age
dictionary_examples: Most of the bikes cost/are over £300.
Children over the age of 12 must have full-price tickets.
They are already $25 million over budget.
learner_examples: We have to dance in a school and over two hundred people [will watch] us. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: from one side or place to another
dictionary_examples: She leaned over and kissed me.
Why don't you come over for dinner on Thursday?
I've got a friend over from Canada this week.
Now we're going over to Wembley for commentary on the Cup Final.
learner_examples: He came over to me and we talked a while. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: describes the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up
dictionary_examples: She turned another page over.
learner_examples: A big truck had turned over and blocked the road and there was no other way for us to go, so we had to wait. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: finished
dictionary_examples: I'll be glad when the competition is over.
I used to have a thriving business and a happy marriage, but that's all over now.
learner_examples: David smiled triumphantly and said, "It is all over!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: happening or done many times
dictionary_examples: I read the article over and over till it made sense.
learner_examples: I've been searching in newspapers over and over again and finally after a couple of days I found something. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
learner_examples: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to do something difficult or unpleasant as soon as you can so that you do not have to worry about it any more
dictionary_examples: I got all my apologies over and done with at the beginning of the meeting.
learner_examples: Not to mention that he knew that he had to get his degree over and done with before he started making serious decisions. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: about
dictionary_examples: The company is being questioned regarding its employment policy.
learner_examples: I apologise to you for missing tomorrow's class as I have to attend a meeting regarding the field trip for our school with the Principal. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malayalam)

pos_items.definition: used to say what the time is when it is a particular number of minutes after an hour
dictionary_examples: It's 5/10/a quarter/20/25/half past three.
I've got to leave at twenty past or I'll miss that train.
learner_examples: The class started the 2nd of June at half past five. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in or to a position that is further than a particular point
dictionary_examples: I live on Station Road, just past the post office.
Three boys went past us on mountain bikes.
Was that Peter who just jogged past in those bright pink shorts?
learner_examples: Turn right past the store and turn left ok? (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: above a particular age or further than a particular point
dictionary_examples: This meat is past its sell-by date.
She's past the age where she needs a babysitter.

pos_items.definition: having happened or existed before now
dictionary_examples: past relationships
I know this from past experience.
learner_examples: I like the place because it has [nice] people, music and all sorts of things [about] past events. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to refer to a period of time before and until the present
dictionary_examples: I've spent the past ten years in and out of jobs.
It's been raining for the past three days.
He was the fifth climber to die on these mountains over the past two days.
learner_examples: Dear Anna, I've just arrived home and couldn't wait to write you to thank you for being so nice, trust[ing] and kind lending me your flat for the past week. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: the form of the verb which is used to show what happened in the past
dictionary_examples: The past of 'change' is 'changed'.

pos_items.definition: the time before the present and all the things that happened then
dictionary_examples: the distant/recent past
In the past, people would bathe once a month.
learner_examples: In the past, we were best friends. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: all of the things that someone has done in their life
dictionary_examples: I knew nothing about his past.
learner_examples: After the film, we went to a restaurant called Adriano, and as the weather was cool, we had a glass of wine and started asking [about] each other's past. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: surrounding or being on all sides of something, or in a circular movement
dictionary_examples: We sat round the fire.
I put my arm round her.
She had a scarf round her neck.
The Moon goes round the Earth.
learner_examples: There [is] a big wood round this lake. (Key English Test; A2; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: to or in different parts of a place
dictionary_examples: The landlord showed me round the house.
I had to go all round town to find a hotel that was open.
learner_examples: Well, she showed me round her hometown and we did some sight-seeing. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: to someone's home
dictionary_examples: Wendy's coming round this afternoon.
I'll go round and see her later.
learner_examples: So would you come round and see me? (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: with a circular movement
dictionary_examples: This switch makes the wheels go round.

pos_items.definition: to the opposite direction
dictionary_examples: She looked round.
Turn the car round and let's go home.
learner_examples: I turned round and I saw that the one who was calling me was the singer!! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: from one place or person to another
dictionary_examples: Could you pass these forms round, please?

pos_items.definition: moving in a circle without stopping
dictionary_examples: We drove round and round trying to find the hotel.
learner_examples: It's not fun to look at an animal who is bored and only walks round and round. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: in the shape of a circle or ball
dictionary_examples: a round hole/stone/table/window
a round face
learner_examples: It is on the round table in your room. (Key English Test; A2; Kannada)

pos_items.definition: the first/second/third/final, etc. stage in a competition
dictionary_examples: He was beaten in the first round.
learner_examples: At five o'clock in the afternoon, the second round of the games [will begin]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: when people clap
dictionary_examples: The crowd gave him a huge round of applause.
learner_examples: It was unbelievable, there was a round of applause and some people couldn't help crying. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: drinks that you buy for a group of people
dictionary_examples: It's your turn to buy the next round.
learner_examples: Rob (her husband) was so happy and in such a splendid mood that he decided to pay [for] a round of beer. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: a group of events that is part of a series
dictionary_examples: a round of interviews
a new round of talks between the two countries
learner_examples: My life was an endless round of parties, and social events. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used with a verb to make an infinitive
dictionary_examples: She agreed to help.
We were starting to feel cold.
I don't know what to do.
Can you tell me how to get there?
It's not likely to happen.
He told me to wait.
Did anyone ask Daniel to book the room?
There's an awful lot of work to be done.
I need to eat something first.
learner_examples: She likes to go shopping with friend[s]. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: used to give the purpose of something or the reason for doing something
dictionary_examples: I'm going there to see my sister.
This tool is used to make holes in leather.
learner_examples: Dear Robbie, I'm writing to tell you some information about what we['re going to] do. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used instead of repeating a verb clause
dictionary_examples: "Are you going tonight?" "I'm certainly hoping to."
"Would you like to come?" "I'd love to."
learner_examples: Yes, I'd love to. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you could have said something in a much stronger way
dictionary_examples: We were surprised, to say the least.
learner_examples: You get slightly bored, to say the least. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: if you do this, or if this is done
dictionary_examples: They want to build a completely new school, but to do so would cost far too much.
I would strongly advise you against taking out a loan of this size. To do so would be a great risk to your business.
learner_examples: It is generally believed that if [a] better education is provided, children are better prepared for adult life. To do so, money is essential. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: If you have time, money, etc. to spare, you have more than you need.
dictionary_examples: I arrived at the station with more than an hour to spare.
learner_examples: I even started to do the shopping on the Net, and I think this is the perfect solution for the busines[s] woman with family and little time to spare. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: If there is a particular amount of time to go, that time remains.
dictionary_examples: There are only two weeks of term to go.
learner_examples: Right now this example is very realistic, and as I have just been told there is only 15 min to go, my stress level, I have to admit, is too high. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about a place or an event where someone goes
dictionary_examples: We went to Prague last year.
We could go to town on the bus.
I have to go to the dentist this morning.
We received another invitation to a wedding this morning.
I've asked Helen and Ben to dinner next week.
You can walk from here to the station in under ten minutes.
She walked over to the window.
He went up to a complete stranger and started talking.
learner_examples: I like go[ing] to London. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to say 'before' the hour when you are saying what time it is
dictionary_examples: It's five to three.

pos_items.definition: used to give information about periods of time
dictionary_examples: The museum is open from Tuesday to Saturday.
learner_examples: We have the class on Monday from 9 o'clock to 10 o'clock in the morning. (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to show who receives something or experiences an action
dictionary_examples: I gave the money to my sister.
Give the gun to me.
Anna was speaking to her mother on the phone.
I lent my bike to my brother.
Who's the letter addressed to?
learner_examples: Please bring it to me tomorrow, because I have to return it to my brother. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show the position of someone or something
dictionary_examples: She stood with her back to the window.
I had my back to them, so I couldn't see what they were doing.
John's standing to the left of Adrian in the photo.
The Yorkshire Dales are twenty miles to the north of the city.
learner_examples: My town is situated to the south of Paris. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say who is treated in a particular way or who or what is affected by something
dictionary_examples: What have you done to your hair?
Her evidence was very helpful to the police.
She was very kind to us.
learner_examples: The waiter was really kind to us. We gave him the key of the car and he drove us home. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show a relationship with someone
dictionary_examples: I've been married to Peter for nine years.
She was an assistant to the chief executive.
learner_examples: She's 38 years old and she's married to a Spanish engineer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things
dictionary_examples: I prefer football to cricket.
She's earning a reasonable wage, but nothing to what she could make in a big company.
learner_examples: I prefer homemade food to re[s]taurant meals. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: until a particular time, state or level is reached
dictionary_examples: It's only two weeks to Christmas.
Unemployment has risen to almost eight million.
She nursed me back to health.

pos_items.definition: used to say where something is fastened or connected
dictionary_examples: The paper was fastened to the wall with tape.
A fast rail service connects us to the city.
learner_examples: My mouth became so dry that my tongue stuck to my palate. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used in phrases which show a range
dictionary_examples: There must have been thirty to thirty-five people there.

pos_items.definition: up to the present time
dictionary_examples: This is her best work to date.
learner_examples: I enclose a copy of my curriculum vitae, which will give you further details about my career to date. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you are giving your own opinion
dictionary_examples: To my mind, the play was rather disappointing.
learner_examples: To my mind, The Picture of Dorian Gray is probably his best novel. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: saying or showing the opposite
dictionary_examples: She claimed she hadn't been involved, despite evidence to the contrary.
learner_examples: Despite claims to the contrary, young people [are] get[ting] more involved in sport[s] activities. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone feels disappointed/relieved/surprised, etc by something
dictionary_examples: To Pierre's disappointment, Monique wasn't at the party.
learner_examples: However, much to my relief, in the end they reached the main square again and all went to the surrounding bars to celebrate the feast in a more relaxed way. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: until you die
dictionary_examples: He was beaten to death by a gang of youths.
learner_examples: She would have been trampled to death as the stampede of furious fans came over her. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: in all the most important ways
dictionary_examples: To all intents and purposes, the project was a disaster.
learner_examples: To all intents and purposes, the qualities needed to achieve success are based on the same ideas. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If something someone says or writes is to the point, it expresses the most important things without extra details.
dictionary_examples: His report was short and to the point.

pos_items.definition: as well as someone wants
dictionary_examples: He won't get paid until he completes the job to my satisfaction.
learner_examples: Should this matter not be solved to my satisfaction, I will have no choice but to place it in the hands of my solicitor. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: in the direction of someone or something
dictionary_examples: She stood up and walked towards him.
He leaned towards his wife and whispered, "Can we go home soon?"
She kept glancing towards the telephone.
learner_examples: We took the train from Paris to Bordeaux, and from there we started to cycle towards the sea. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in relation to something or someone
dictionary_examples: They've always been very friendly towards me.
He feels a lot of anger towards his father.
She always has a positive attitude towards life.
learner_examples: His parents were very cold towards me. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: near to a time or place
dictionary_examples: Our seats were towards the back of the theatre.
I often get hungry towards the middle of the morning.
We're getting towards winter and it's getting dark earlier.
learner_examples: If I [had] told somebody fifty years ago that women w[ould] have leading political positions towards the end of the century, he or she would have most probably considered [me] as being mad. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: for the purpose of buying or achieving something

The work that students do during the term counts towards their final grade.

learner_examples: Should this matter not be solved to my satisfaction, I will have no choice but to place it in the hands of my solicitor. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: from a time in the past until a later time or until now
dictionary_examples: England have not won the World Cup in football since 1966.
It was the hottest October since records began.

pos_items.definition: from a time in the past until a later time or until now
dictionary_examples: He's been much happier since he started his new job.
I've known Tim since he was seven.
learner_examples: I was really surprised when I read the e-mail because I haven't heard from you since I visited you last year. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Romansch)

pos_items.definition: because
dictionary_examples: Since we've got a few minutes to wait for the train, let's have a cup of coffee.
learner_examples: Since my mother has surgery tomorrow, I will not [be able to] come to your class. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: from a time in the past until a later time or until now
dictionary_examples: Emma went to work in New York a year ago, and we haven't seen her since.
He started working for the company when he left school, and has been there ever since.
I've long since forgotten any Latin I ever learned.
learner_examples: It was my grandmother who introduced me to teddy bears and she wanted me to love them as she did. When she died, I got all her bears and have been taking care of them ever since. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two different things or amounts
dictionary_examples: My son is a lot taller than my daughter.
You always walk faster than I do!
You're earlier than usual.
learner_examples: Cirencester is smaller than Swindon. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: used with 'more' or 'less' to compare numbers or amounts
dictionary_examples: I spent more than I intended to.
It cost less than I expected.
learner_examples: I want to sell my "English Grammar" book, it's a great book, simple to read, just the right book for you, and I [am] sell[ing] it at less than half price; INCREDIBLE!! (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: until
dictionary_examples: We waited till half past six for you.
Up till 1918, women in Britain were not allowed to vote.
learner_examples: I am going to be busy till 10:30 am. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: until
dictionary_examples: How long is it till your baby is due?
learner_examples: Everything seemed normal till I arrived in Berlin. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: from one end or side of something to the other
dictionary_examples: We drove through the tunnel.
The River Seine flows through Paris.
The sun was shining through the window.
She cut through the wire.
They walked slowly through the woods.
learner_examples: So, through the windows I can see [the sea] and it is wonderful. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: from the start to the end of something
dictionary_examples: He worked through the night.
The phone rang halfway through the programme.
learner_examples: It begins in the evening and goes through the night, because it's a very long play. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: because of someone or something, or with someone's help
dictionary_examples: I got the job through a friend of my mum's.
He became ill through eating undercooked meat.
learner_examples: I knew her through my husband, she is my husband's friend's wife. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: from one end or side to another
dictionary_examples: He opened the door and walked through.
The needle just wouldn't go through.
learner_examples: A few bombs crashed close to the car but we managed to get through. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: A through train goes all the way from one place to another place without the passenger having to change trains.
dictionary_examples: We caught the through train to Manchester.
learner_examples: Then go to the information desk and ask about the time of departure of through trains to Lodz. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

learner_examples: I knew her through my husband, she is my husband's friend's wife. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: from one end or side to another
dictionary_examples: He opened the door and walked through.
The needle just wouldn't go through.
learner_examples: A few bombs crashed close to the car but we managed to get through. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: A through train goes all the way from one place to another place without the passenger having to change trains.
dictionary_examples: We caught the through train to Manchester.
learner_examples: Then go to the information desk and ask about the time of departure of through trains to Lodz. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used with a verb to make an infinitive
dictionary_examples: She agreed to help.
We were starting to feel cold.
I don't know what to do.
Can you tell me how to get there?
It's not likely to happen.
He told me to wait.
Did anyone ask Daniel to book the room?
There's an awful lot of work to be done.
I need to eat something first.
learner_examples: She likes to go shopping with friend[s]. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bulgarian)

pos_items.definition: used to give the purpose of something or the reason for doing something
dictionary_examples: I'm going there to see my sister.
This tool is used to make holes in leather.
learner_examples: Dear Robbie, I'm writing to tell you some information about what we['re going to] do. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used instead of repeating a verb clause
dictionary_examples: "Are you going tonight?" "I'm certainly hoping to."
"Would you like to come?" "I'd love to."
learner_examples: Yes, I'd love to. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you could have said something in a much stronger way
dictionary_examples: We were surprised, to say the least.
learner_examples: You get slightly bored, to say the least. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: if you do this, or if this is done
dictionary_examples: They want to build a completely new school, but to do so would cost far too much.
I would strongly advise you against taking out a loan of this size. To do so would be a great risk to your business.
learner_examples: It is generally believed that if [a] better education is provided, children are better prepared for adult life. To do so, money is essential. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: If you have time, money, etc. to spare, you have more than you need.
dictionary_examples: I arrived at the station with more than an hour to spare.
learner_examples: I even started to do the shopping on the Net, and I think this is the perfect solution for the busines[s] woman with family and little time to spare. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: If there is a particular amount of time to go, that time remains.
dictionary_examples: There are only two weeks of term to go.
learner_examples: Right now this example is very realistic, and as I have just been told there is only 15 min to go, my stress level, I have to admit, is too high. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about a place or an event where someone goes
dictionary_examples: We went to Prague last year.
We could go to town on the bus.
I have to go to the dentist this morning.
We received another invitation to a wedding this morning.
I've asked Helen and Ben to dinner next week.
You can walk from here to the station in under ten minutes.
She walked over to the window.
He went up to a complete stranger and started talking.
learner_examples: I like go[ing] to London. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to say 'before' the hour when you are saying what time it is
dictionary_examples: It's five to three.

pos_items.definition: used to give information about periods of time
dictionary_examples: The museum is open from Tuesday to Saturday.
learner_examples: We have the class on Monday from 9 o'clock to 10 o'clock in the morning. (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to show who receives something or experiences an action
dictionary_examples: I gave the money to my sister.
Give the gun to me.
Anna was speaking to her mother on the phone.
I lent my bike to my brother.
Who's the letter addressed to?
learner_examples: Please bring it to me tomorrow, because I have to return it to my brother. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show the position of someone or something
dictionary_examples: She stood with her back to the window.
I had my back to them, so I couldn't see what they were doing.
John's standing to the left of Adrian in the photo.
The Yorkshire Dales are twenty miles to the north of the city.
learner_examples: My town is situated to the south of Paris. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say who is treated in a particular way or who or what is affected by something
dictionary_examples: What have you done to your hair?
Her evidence was very helpful to the police.
She was very kind to us.
learner_examples: The waiter was really kind to us. We gave him the key of the car and he drove us home. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show a relationship with someone
dictionary_examples: I've been married to Peter for nine years.
She was an assistant to the chief executive.
learner_examples: She's 38 years old and she's married to a Spanish engineer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things
dictionary_examples: I prefer football to cricket.
She's earning a reasonable wage, but nothing to what she could make in a big company.
learner_examples: I prefer homemade food to re[s]taurant meals. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: until a particular time, state or level is reached
dictionary_examples: It's only two weeks to Christmas.
Unemployment has risen to almost eight million.
She nursed me back to health.

pos_items.definition: used to say where something is fastened or connected
dictionary_examples: The paper was fastened to the wall with tape.
A fast rail service connects us to the city.
learner_examples: My mouth became so dry that my tongue stuck to my palate. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used in phrases which show a range
dictionary_examples: There must have been thirty to thirty-five people there.

pos_items.definition: up to the present time
dictionary_examples: This is her best work to date.
learner_examples: I enclose a copy of my curriculum vitae, which will give you further details about my career to date. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you are giving your own opinion
dictionary_examples: To my mind, the play was rather disappointing.
learner_examples: To my mind, The Picture of Dorian Gray is probably his best novel. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: saying or showing the opposite
dictionary_examples: She claimed she hadn't been involved, despite evidence to the contrary.
learner_examples: Despite claims to the contrary, young people [are] get[ting] more involved in sport[s] activities. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone feels disappointed/relieved/surprised, etc by something
dictionary_examples: To Pierre's disappointment, Monique wasn't at the party.
learner_examples: However, much to my relief, in the end they reached the main square again and all went to the surrounding bars to celebrate the feast in a more relaxed way. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: until you die
dictionary_examples: He was beaten to death by a gang of youths.
learner_examples: She would have been trampled to death as the stampede of furious fans came over her. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: in all the most important ways
dictionary_examples: To all intents and purposes, the project was a disaster.
learner_examples: To all intents and purposes, the qualities needed to achieve success are based on the same ideas. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If something someone says or writes is to the point, it expresses the most important things without extra details.
dictionary_examples: His report was short and to the point.

dictionary_examples: He won't get paid until he completes the job to my satisfaction.
learner_examples: Should this matter not be solved to my satisfaction, I will have no choice but to place it in the hands of my solicitor. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

learner_examples: Dear Robbie, I'm writing to tell you some information about what we['re going to] do. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used instead of repeating a verb clause
dictionary_examples: "Are you going tonight?" "I'm certainly hoping to."
"Would you like to come?" "I'd love to."
learner_examples: Yes, I'd love to. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you could have said something in a much stronger way
dictionary_examples: We were surprised, to say the least.
learner_examples: You get slightly bored, to say the least. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: if you do this, or if this is done
dictionary_examples: They want to build a completely new school, but to do so would cost far too much.
I would strongly advise you against taking out a loan of this size. To do so would be a great risk to your business.
learner_examples: It is generally believed that if [a] better education is provided, children are better prepared for adult life. To do so, money is essential. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: If you have time, money, etc. to spare, you have more than you need.
dictionary_examples: I arrived at the station with more than an hour to spare.
learner_examples: I even started to do the shopping on the Net, and I think this is the perfect solution for the busines[s] woman with family and little time to spare. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: If there is a particular amount of time to go, that time remains.
dictionary_examples: There are only two weeks of term to go.
learner_examples: Right now this example is very realistic, and as I have just been told there is only 15 min to go, my stress level, I have to admit, is too high. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: used to talk about a place or an event where someone goes
dictionary_examples: We went to Prague last year.
We could go to town on the bus.
I have to go to the dentist this morning.
We received another invitation to a wedding this morning.
I've asked Helen and Ben to dinner next week.
You can walk from here to the station in under ten minutes.
She walked over to the window.
He went up to a complete stranger and started talking.
learner_examples: I like go[ing] to London. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to say 'before' the hour when you are saying what time it is
dictionary_examples: It's five to three.

pos_items.definition: used to give information about periods of time
dictionary_examples: The museum is open from Tuesday to Saturday.
learner_examples: We have the class on Monday from 9 o'clock to 10 o'clock in the morning. (Key English Test; A2; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to show who receives something or experiences an action
dictionary_examples: I gave the money to my sister.
Give the gun to me.
Anna was speaking to her mother on the phone.
I lent my bike to my brother.
Who's the letter addressed to?
learner_examples: Please bring it to me tomorrow, because I have to return it to my brother. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show the position of someone or something
dictionary_examples: She stood with her back to the window.
I had my back to them, so I couldn't see what they were doing.
John's standing to the left of Adrian in the photo.
The Yorkshire Dales are twenty miles to the north of the city.
learner_examples: My town is situated to the south of Paris. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say who is treated in a particular way or who or what is affected by something
dictionary_examples: What have you done to your hair?
Her evidence was very helpful to the police.
She was very kind to us.
learner_examples: The waiter was really kind to us. We gave him the key of the car and he drove us home. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to show a relationship with someone
dictionary_examples: I've been married to Peter for nine years.
She was an assistant to the chief executive.
learner_examples: She's 38 years old and she's married to a Spanish engineer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things
dictionary_examples: I prefer football to cricket.
She's earning a reasonable wage, but nothing to what she could make in a big company.
learner_examples: I prefer homemade food to re[s]taurant meals. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: until a particular time, state or level is reached
dictionary_examples: It's only two weeks to Christmas.
Unemployment has risen to almost eight million.
She nursed me back to health.

pos_items.definition: used to say where something is fastened or connected
dictionary_examples: The paper was fastened to the wall with tape.
A fast rail service connects us to the city.
learner_examples: My mouth became so dry that my tongue stuck to my palate. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: used in phrases which show a range
dictionary_examples: There must have been thirty to thirty-five people there.

pos_items.definition: up to the present time
dictionary_examples: This is her best work to date.
learner_examples: I enclose a copy of my curriculum vitae, which will give you further details about my career to date. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you are giving your own opinion
dictionary_examples: To my mind, the play was rather disappointing.
learner_examples: To my mind, The Picture of Dorian Gray is probably his best novel. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

pos_items.definition: saying or showing the opposite
dictionary_examples: She claimed she hadn't been involved, despite evidence to the contrary.
learner_examples: Despite claims to the contrary, young people [are] get[ting] more involved in sport[s] activities. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone feels disappointed/relieved/surprised, etc by something
dictionary_examples: To Pierre's disappointment, Monique wasn't at the party.
learner_examples: However, much to my relief, in the end they reached the main square again and all went to the surrounding bars to celebrate the feast in a more relaxed way. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: until you die
dictionary_examples: He was beaten to death by a gang of youths.
learner_examples: She would have been trampled to death as the stampede of furious fans came over her. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: in all the most important ways
dictionary_examples: To all intents and purposes, the project was a disaster.
learner_examples: To all intents and purposes, the qualities needed to achieve success are based on the same ideas. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If something someone says or writes is to the point, it expresses the most important things without extra details.
dictionary_examples: His report was short and to the point.

pos_items.definition: as well as someone wants
dictionary_examples: He won't get paid until he completes the job to my satisfaction.
learner_examples: Should this matter not be solved to my satisfaction, I will have no choice but to place it in the hands of my solicitor. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)

pos_items.definition: in the direction of someone or something

learner_examples: We took the train from Paris to Bordeaux, and from there we started to cycle towards the sea. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in relation to something or someone
dictionary_examples: They've always been very friendly towards me.
He feels a lot of anger towards his father.
She always has a positive attitude towards life.
learner_examples: His parents were very cold towards me. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: near to a time or place
dictionary_examples: Our seats were towards the back of the theatre.
I often get hungry towards the middle of the morning.
We're getting towards winter and it's getting dark earlier.
learner_examples: If I [had] told somebody fifty years ago that women w[ould] have leading political positions towards the end of the century, he or she would have most probably considered [me] as being mad. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

pos_items.definition: for the purpose of buying or achieving something

pos_items.definition: in every part of a place
dictionary_examples: The same laws apply throughout much of Europe.

dictionary_examples: Once upon a time there was a beautiful princess.
learner_examples: Once upon a time there was a very poor family. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: on
dictionary_examples: Upon her head she wore a black velvet hat.
