learner_examples: He answered with a smile upon his face, 'As I just told everybody else, you will have the results by the end of June.' (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: going through or stopping at a place on the way to another place
dictionary_examples: The train to Utrecht goes via Amsterdam.
learner_examples: Two years ago I travel[l]ed to Canada via Italy. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: using a particular machine, system or person to send or recieve something
dictionary_examples: Reports are coming in via satellite.
I only found out about it via my sister.
learner_examples: I hate shopping via [the] internet. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: below something, or below the surface of something
dictionary_examples: He hid under the bed.
They were standing under a tree.
She was holding a file under her arm.
She pushed her bag under the table.
He could only keep his head under the water for a few seconds.
learner_examples: I like my bedroom, because there [is] a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: less than a number, amount, or age
dictionary_examples: All items cost/are under a pound.
You can buy the whole set of DVDs for just under £30.
The discount applies only to children under (the age of) ten.
Under-5s get in free.
If you get under 50%, you've failed the exam.
learner_examples: I saw an advertisement in front of my house: the coffee bar is looking for some waiters aged under 23 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a particular state or condition
dictionary_examples: The President is under pressure to resign.
Under no circumstances should the festival become too specialized.
learner_examples: I am used to working under pressure. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: being affected by something at the present time
dictionary_examples: The town is once again under attack.
The cause of the fire is still under investigation.
A new 16-screen cinema is under construction.
Several different plans are under discussion.
We are working hard to get the situation under control.
learner_examples: Everything was under control, the remote detonator had worked perfectly well. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to think or understand a particular stated thing
dictionary_examples: I was under the impression (that) you didn't get on too well.
He was under the mistaken impression (that) you were married.
learner_examples: I am under the impression that people generally exercise a little, but if they eat the wrong food every day, it won't help. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: If you say something under your breath, you say it very quietly so that other people cannot hear it.
dictionary_examples: He was muttering curses under his breath.
learner_examples: "We must have taken a wrong turn somewhere..." he kept muttering under his breath. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: Australia, or in Australia
dictionary_examples: She was born in Scotland, but she's been living down under for 22 years.
learner_examples: Last year a good friend of mine and I went to Australia. After a couple of days of doing some sightseeing and sunbathing on bea[u]tiful sandy beaches, we decided that we need[ed] to get something more out of our stay down under. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something bad happens under your nose, it happens close to you but you do not notice it.
dictionary_examples: They were stealing money from under my nose.
learner_examples: You will be surprised that there was something right under your nose that you could not live without. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: to be already happening
dictionary_examples: Building work is already under way.
learner_examples: Sociologists are well-aware of the fact and experiments are under way to counterbalance these disadvantages. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to feel ill
dictionary_examples: I'm feeling a bit under the weather this morning.
learner_examples: Ann was a bit under the weather, [and] she felt quite lonely in her big flat. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to say that people or things are in a place together or are doing something together
dictionary_examples: I was with Sylvia at the time.
He lives with his grandmother.
I'm going to France with a couple of friends.
Ingrid Bergman starred with Humphrey Bogart in the film 'Casablanca'.
learner_examples: On Sunday afternoon, she goes with her husband and her son to the swim[m]ing pool. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: having or including something
dictionary_examples: a house with a swimming pool
a woman with brown eyes
learner_examples: I want you to cook rice with fish and olives. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: using something
dictionary_examples: She hit him over the head with a tennis racket.
Fix the two pieces together with glue.
learner_examples: I can print [the] advertisement and tickets with my computer. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say what fills, covers, etc. something

learner_examples: It was like throwing her into a pool filled with ice. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: used to describe the way someone does something
dictionary_examples: He plays with great skill.
learner_examples: People can do more things and with more energy when [they are] listening to music. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: I was shaking with fear.
I can't work with all that noise going on.
learner_examples: It was Tuesday the 13th and the fact that I was very superstitious made me tremble with fear. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: relating to something or someone
dictionary_examples: There's something wrong with the car.

pos_items.definition: relating to a particular thing
dictionary_examples: I am writing with respect to your letter of 24 June.
learner_examples: With respect to the ages of the members, they are between fifteen and twenty years old. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: using something to help you
dictionary_examples: She can walk with the aid of a stick.
learner_examples: The newest computer can handle data that human brains cannot and therefore all scientific research [is] carried out with the aid of computers. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: with a very high score or with great success

pos_items.sense_title: with a view to doing sth
pos_items.definition: so that you can do something

pos_items.definition: in an excited or anxious way

Under-5s get in free.
If you get under 50%, you've failed the exam.
learner_examples: I saw an advertisement in front of my house: the coffee bar is looking for some waiters aged under 23 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a particular state or condition
dictionary_examples: The President is under pressure to resign.
Under no circumstances should the festival become too specialized.
learner_examples: I am used to working under pressure. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: being affected by something at the present time
dictionary_examples: The town is once again under attack.
The cause of the fire is still under investigation.
A new 16-screen cinema is under construction.
Several different plans are under discussion.
We are working hard to get the situation under control.
learner_examples: Everything was under control, the remote detonator had worked perfectly well. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to think or understand a particular stated thing
dictionary_examples: I was under the impression (that) you didn't get on too well.
He was under the mistaken impression (that) you were married.
learner_examples: I am under the impression that people generally exercise a little, but if they eat the wrong food every day, it won't help. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: If you say something under your breath, you say it very quietly so that other people cannot hear it.
dictionary_examples: He was muttering curses under his breath.
learner_examples: "We must have taken a wrong turn somewhere..." he kept muttering under his breath. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: Australia, or in Australia
dictionary_examples: She was born in Scotland, but she's been living down under for 22 years.
learner_examples: Last year a good friend of mine and I went to Australia. After a couple of days of doing some sightseeing and sunbathing on bea[u]tiful sandy beaches, we decided that we need[ed] to get something more out of our stay down under. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something bad happens under your nose, it happens close to you but you do not notice it.
dictionary_examples: They were stealing money from under my nose.
learner_examples: You will be surprised that there was something right under your nose that you could not live without. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: to be already happening
dictionary_examples: Building work is already under way.
learner_examples: Sociologists are well-aware of the fact and experiments are under way to counterbalance these disadvantages. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to feel ill
dictionary_examples: I'm feeling a bit under the weather this morning.
learner_examples: Ann was a bit under the weather, [and] she felt quite lonely in her big flat. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: not having, using, or doing something
dictionary_examples: I've come out without my umbrella.
You look nice without make-up.
You shouldn't drive for more than three hours without taking/having a break.
learner_examples: I have an exam tomorrow and I cannot study without the folder. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: when someone is not with someone else
dictionary_examples: I couldn't have done it without you.
You can start the meeting without me.
learner_examples: Majorca is wonderful, but I feel lonely without you. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: immediately
dictionary_examples: This problem needs to be dealt with without delay.
learner_examples: Firstly, the programme began on time at midday without delay. (First Certificate in English; B2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: under or below something
dictionary_examples: The tunnel goes right underneath the city.
They found a bomb underneath the car.
learner_examples: She was dressed like a princess, after spending the whole day looking for an appropriate dress, which she finally managed to find underneath her bed. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: under or below
dictionary_examples: Florian was wearing a dark jacket with a red shirt underneath.
learner_examples: The rock was about 70m high and there was water underneath. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used to say that people or things are in a place together or are doing something together
dictionary_examples: I was with Sylvia at the time.
He lives with his grandmother.
I'm going to France with a couple of friends.
Ingrid Bergman starred with Humphrey Bogart in the film 'Casablanca'.
learner_examples: On Sunday afternoon, she goes with her husband and her son to the swim[m]ing pool. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: having or including something
dictionary_examples: a house with a swimming pool
a woman with brown eyes
learner_examples: I want you to cook rice with fish and olives. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: using something
dictionary_examples: She hit him over the head with a tennis racket.
Fix the two pieces together with glue.
learner_examples: I can print [the] advertisement and tickets with my computer. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say what fills, covers, etc. something
dictionary_examples: a bucket filled with water
She filled the jug with cream.
learner_examples: It was like throwing her into a pool filled with ice. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: used to describe the way someone does something
dictionary_examples: He plays with great skill.
learner_examples: People can do more things and with more energy when [they are] listening to music. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: I was shaking with fear.
I can't work with all that noise going on.
learner_examples: It was Tuesday the 13th and the fact that I was very superstitious made me tremble with fear. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: relating to something or someone
dictionary_examples: There's something wrong with the car.
learner_examples: [It]'s such a shame when people use [computers] badly, just for damaging and making things worse, because if there's something wrong with them, almost everything is wrong [with] us too. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: relating to a particular thing
dictionary_examples: I am writing with respect to your letter of 24 June.
learner_examples: With respect to the ages of the members, they are between fifteen and twenty years old. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: using something to help you
dictionary_examples: She can walk with the aid of a stick.
learner_examples: The newest computer can handle data that human brains cannot and therefore all scientific research [is] carried out with the aid of computers. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: with a very high score or with great success
dictionary_examples: He passed the entrance exam with flying colours.
learner_examples: I worked intens[ive]ly on the course and I passed with flying colours. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: with a view to doing sth
pos_items.definition: so that you can do something
dictionary_examples: He's doing some improvements on the house with a view to selling it.
learner_examples: The purpose of this report is to assess the success of the latest tour our sports club organised and make relevant suggestions with a view to enhancing future trips. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: without using any type of tool or weapon when doing something that requires a lot of strength
dictionary_examples: He wrestled the lion to the ground with his bare hands.
learner_examples: You could tell your grand-children about the good old days when you hunted for mammoths and skinned them with your bare hands, just a few million years back (sigh: "seems like yesterday"). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in an excited or anxious way
dictionary_examples: I waited with bated breath as the results were read out.
learner_examples: Nevertheless, a huge number of scientists carrying out very useful research, [and] composers, actors, [and] artists making us watch their creations with bated breath, do not earn [as much] money as a lot of outstanding sportsmen do. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used by someone to express good wishes when they give you something free, for example in a restaurant
dictionary_examples: Please accept this champagne with the compliments of the manager.
learner_examples: The guest can also choose from a selection of wonderful desserts such as mousse au chocolat with fresh ras[p]berries before finishing his/her meal with a rose lique[u]r - with the compliments of the house (and the bill). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: before a particular period of time has finished
dictionary_examples: The ambulance arrived within 10 minutes.
This product should be eaten within three days.
learner_examples: I will return it to you within four days. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: less than a particular distance from something
dictionary_examples: Two-thirds of Californians live within 15 miles of the coast.
The hotel is within easy reach of the airport.
learner_examples: By the way, [the] receptionist told me that the scenery round the lake is very beautiful and that the Butterfly Farm and the monument shown on your map are within easy reach. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: not outside the limits of something
dictionary_examples: We came within five points of beating them.
The project was completed well within budget.
learner_examples: Similarly [the] visitor has also shown responsibility to remain within [the] limits of the society he is moving [in], so that he cannot cause any hurt or harm to local culture. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Panjabi)

pos_items.definition: inside an area, group, or system
dictionary_examples: a dispute within the department
There's a pharmacy within the hospital building.
learner_examples: Dear Sir or Madam, I am writing to you, as requested, in order to ensure that the training - whose purpose is to help the staff improve its communications with the other departments within the company - is effective and not just a waste of time. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: avoiding behaviour that is extreme or silly
dictionary_examples: You can wear what you want, within limits.
learner_examples: They should be given a choice of food, within limits. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: possible for someone to achieve
dictionary_examples: Winning the championship suddenly seemed within their reach.
learner_examples: We have decided to take action to prevent further damage being inflicted, and are convinced the task is fully within our reach. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something is within reason, it is acceptable and possible.
dictionary_examples: We can wear what we like to the office, within reason.
learner_examples: Although this view may seem too harsh and hard-hearted, I believe it is within reason. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used to say that one team or person is competing against another
dictionary_examples: Tomorrow's game is Newcastle versus Arsenal.
learner_examples: Starting in chronological order you can see the first game - Argentina versus Germany - which was a revenge for the final competition in the previous World Cup, '88. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things or ideas, especially when you have to choose between them
dictionary_examples: private education versus state education
learner_examples: Mobile phones - fashion versus utility Nowadays, [everywhere] you look, there is someone speaking [on] a mobile phone. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: going through or stopping at a place on the way to another place
dictionary_examples: The train to Utrecht goes via Amsterdam.
learner_examples: Two years ago I travel[l]ed to Canada via Italy. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: using a particular machine, system or person to send or recieve something
dictionary_examples: Reports are coming in via satellite.
I only found out about it via my sister.
learner_examples: I hate shopping via [the] internet. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: different from someone or something
dictionary_examples: The furniture was unlike anything she had ever seen.
Dan's actually quite nice, unlike his father.
Unlike you, I'm not a great dancer.
learner_examples: In fact the Hotel Astrid is now closed so I had to stay at the Riverside Hotel, [whi]ch offers great savings for students, unlike the Hotel Royal [whi]ch is quite expensive. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: not typical of someone or something
dictionary_examples: It's unlike her to be quiet - was there something wrong?
learner_examples: Over the weeks he was getting more and more exhausted and started reducing [his] hours of work. That was so unlike him. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: towards or in a higher place or position
dictionary_examples: She looked up and smiled at me.
This road goes up into the Andes.
The water was up to the level of the windows.
learner_examples: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. I looked up and I saw my friend on the other side of the concert [hall]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

pos_items.definition: to walk directly towards someone or something until you are next to them

learner_examples: She came up to him to help him with the luggage. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay)

pos_items.definition: not in bed
dictionary_examples: I stayed up all night finishing this report.
learner_examples: That night we were up until late talking and after a couple of days she left. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish)

pos_items.definition: If an action or decision is up to someone, they are responsible for doing or making it.

learner_examples: This is my opinion but it's up to you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to be doing or planning something
dictionary_examples: What are you up to at the moment?

learner_examples: What have you been up to? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: to a greater degree, amount, volume, etc.
dictionary_examples: Please speak up, I can't hear you.

The cost of car insurance is up, but not very much.
learner_examples: Moreover the microphone suddenly wouldn't work anymore, and even though I desperately tried to speak up, people began to lose interest in both my speech and me and simply started to talk to each other instead. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: to be of bad quality
dictionary_examples: Her latest novel isn't up to much.

pos_items.definition: relating to something or someone
dictionary_examples: There's something wrong with the car.
learner_examples: [It]'s such a shame when people use [computers] badly, just for damaging and making things worse, because if there's something wrong with them, almost everything is wrong [with] us too. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: relating to a particular thing
dictionary_examples: I am writing with respect to your letter of 24 June.
learner_examples: With respect to the ages of the members, they are between fifteen and twenty years old. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: using something to help you
dictionary_examples: She can walk with the aid of a stick.
learner_examples: The newest computer can handle data that human brains cannot and therefore all scientific research [is] carried out with the aid of computers. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: with a very high score or with great success
dictionary_examples: He passed the entrance exam with flying colours.
learner_examples: I worked intens[ive]ly on the course and I passed with flying colours. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: with a view to doing sth
pos_items.definition: so that you can do something
dictionary_examples: He's doing some improvements on the house with a view to selling it.
learner_examples: The purpose of this report is to assess the success of the latest tour our sports club organised and make relevant suggestions with a view to enhancing future trips. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: without using any type of tool or weapon when doing something that requires a lot of strength
dictionary_examples: He wrestled the lion to the ground with his bare hands.
learner_examples: You could tell your grand-children about the good old days when you hunted for mammoths and skinned them with your bare hands, just a few million years back (sigh: "seems like yesterday"). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in an excited or anxious way
dictionary_examples: I waited with bated breath as the results were read out.
learner_examples: Nevertheless, a huge number of scientists carrying out very useful research, [and] composers, actors, [and] artists making us watch their creations with bated breath, do not earn [as much] money as a lot of outstanding sportsmen do. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used by someone to express good wishes when they give you something free, for example in a restaurant
dictionary_examples: Please accept this champagne with the compliments of the manager.
learner_examples: The guest can also choose from a selection of wonderful desserts such as mousse au chocolat with fresh ras[p]berries before finishing his/her meal with a rose lique[u]r - with the compliments of the house (and the bill). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: used to say that people or things are in a place together or are doing something together
dictionary_examples: I was with Sylvia at the time.
He lives with his grandmother.
I'm going to France with a couple of friends.
Ingrid Bergman starred with Humphrey Bogart in the film 'Casablanca'.
learner_examples: On Sunday afternoon, she goes with her husband and her son to the swim[m]ing pool. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: having or including something
dictionary_examples: a house with a swimming pool
a woman with brown eyes
learner_examples: I want you to cook rice with fish and olives. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

pos_items.definition: using something
dictionary_examples: She hit him over the head with a tennis racket.
Fix the two pieces together with glue.
learner_examples: I can print [the] advertisement and tickets with my computer. (Key English Test; A2; French)

pos_items.definition: used to say what fills, covers, etc. something
dictionary_examples: a bucket filled with water
She filled the jug with cream.
learner_examples: It was like throwing her into a pool filled with ice. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

pos_items.definition: used to describe the way someone does something
dictionary_examples: He plays with great skill.
learner_examples: People can do more things and with more energy when [they are] listening to music. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: I was shaking with fear.
I can't work with all that noise going on.
learner_examples: It was Tuesday the 13th and the fact that I was very superstitious made me tremble with fear. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: relating to something or someone
dictionary_examples: There's something wrong with the car.
learner_examples: [It]'s such a shame when people use [computers] badly, just for damaging and making things worse, because if there's something wrong with them, almost everything is wrong [with] us too. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

learner_examples: I worked intens[ive]ly on the course and I passed with flying colours. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish)

pos_items.sense_title: with a view to doing sth
pos_items.definition: so that you can do something
dictionary_examples: He's doing some improvements on the house with a view to selling it.
learner_examples: The purpose of this report is to assess the success of the latest tour our sports club organised and make relevant suggestions with a view to enhancing future trips. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: without using any type of tool or weapon when doing something that requires a lot of strength
dictionary_examples: He wrestled the lion to the ground with his bare hands.
learner_examples: You could tell your grand-children about the good old days when you hunted for mammoths and skinned them with your bare hands, just a few million years back (sigh: "seems like yesterday"). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: in an excited or anxious way
dictionary_examples: I waited with bated breath as the results were read out.
learner_examples: Nevertheless, a huge number of scientists carrying out very useful research, [and] composers, actors, [and] artists making us watch their creations with bated breath, do not earn [as much] money as a lot of outstanding sportsmen do. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used by someone to express good wishes when they give you something free, for example in a restaurant
dictionary_examples: Please accept this champagne with the compliments of the manager.
learner_examples: The guest can also choose from a selection of wonderful desserts such as mousse au chocolat with fresh ras[p]berries before finishing his/her meal with a rose lique[u]r - with the compliments of the house (and the bill). (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: before a particular period of time has finished
dictionary_examples: The ambulance arrived within 10 minutes.
This product should be eaten within three days.
learner_examples: I will return it to you within four days. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: less than a particular distance from something
dictionary_examples: Two-thirds of Californians live within 15 miles of the coast.
The hotel is within easy reach of the airport.
learner_examples: By the way, [the] receptionist told me that the scenery round the lake is very beautiful and that the Butterfly Farm and the monument shown on your map are within easy reach. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

pos_items.definition: not outside the limits of something
dictionary_examples: We came within five points of beating them.
The project was completed well within budget.
learner_examples: Similarly [the] visitor has also shown responsibility to remain within [the] limits of the society he is moving [in], so that he cannot cause any hurt or harm to local culture. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Panjabi)

pos_items.definition: inside an area, group, or system
dictionary_examples: a dispute within the department
There's a pharmacy within the hospital building.
learner_examples: Dear Sir or Madam, I am writing to you, as requested, in order to ensure that the training - whose purpose is to help the staff improve its communications with the other departments within the company - is effective and not just a waste of time. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: avoiding behaviour that is extreme or silly
dictionary_examples: You can wear what you want, within limits.
learner_examples: They should be given a choice of food, within limits. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: possible for someone to achieve
dictionary_examples: Winning the championship suddenly seemed within their reach.
learner_examples: We have decided to take action to prevent further damage being inflicted, and are convinced the task is fully within our reach. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something is within reason, it is acceptable and possible.
dictionary_examples: We can wear what we like to the office, within reason.
learner_examples: Although this view may seem too harsh and hard-hearted, I believe it is within reason. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: below something, or below the surface of something
dictionary_examples: He hid under the bed.
They were standing under a tree.
She was holding a file under her arm.
She pushed her bag under the table.
He could only keep his head under the water for a few seconds.
learner_examples: I like my bedroom, because there [is] a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: less than a number, amount, or age
dictionary_examples: All items cost/are under a pound.
You can buy the whole set of DVDs for just under £30.
The discount applies only to children under (the age of) ten.
Under-5s get in free.
If you get under 50%, you've failed the exam.
learner_examples: I saw an advertisement in front of my house: the coffee bar is looking for some waiters aged under 23 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: in a particular state or condition
dictionary_examples: The President is under pressure to resign.
Under no circumstances should the festival become too specialized.
learner_examples: I am used to working under pressure. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: being affected by something at the present time
dictionary_examples: The town is once again under attack.
The cause of the fire is still under investigation.
A new 16-screen cinema is under construction.
Several different plans are under discussion.
We are working hard to get the situation under control.
learner_examples: Everything was under control, the remote detonator had worked perfectly well. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to think or understand a particular stated thing
dictionary_examples: I was under the impression (that) you didn't get on too well.
He was under the mistaken impression (that) you were married.
learner_examples: I am under the impression that people generally exercise a little, but if they eat the wrong food every day, it won't help. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

pos_items.definition: If you say something under your breath, you say it very quietly so that other people cannot hear it.
dictionary_examples: He was muttering curses under his breath.
learner_examples: "We must have taken a wrong turn somewhere..." he kept muttering under his breath. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: Australia, or in Australia
dictionary_examples: She was born in Scotland, but she's been living down under for 22 years.
learner_examples: Last year a good friend of mine and I went to Australia. After a couple of days of doing some sightseeing and sunbathing on bea[u]tiful sandy beaches, we decided that we need[ed] to get something more out of our stay down under. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: If something bad happens under your nose, it happens close to you but you do not notice it.
dictionary_examples: They were stealing money from under my nose.
learner_examples: You will be surprised that there was something right under your nose that you could not live without. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean)

pos_items.definition: to be already happening
dictionary_examples: Building work is already under way.
learner_examples: Sociologists are well-aware of the fact and experiments are under way to counterbalance these disadvantages. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: to feel ill
dictionary_examples: I'm feeling a bit under the weather this morning.
learner_examples: Ann was a bit under the weather, [and] she felt quite lonely in her big flat. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to say that one team or person is competing against another
dictionary_examples: Tomorrow's game is Newcastle versus Arsenal.
learner_examples: Starting in chronological order you can see the first game - Argentina versus Germany - which was a revenge for the final competition in the previous World Cup, '88. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to compare two things or ideas, especially when you have to choose between them
dictionary_examples: private education versus state education
learner_examples: Mobile phones - fashion versus utility Nowadays, [everywhere] you look, there is someone speaking [on] a mobile phone. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)
